Then there were some other bumps (merger and reacquisitions) that came along. In the meantime, I completed my MBA there. Then layoffs starting happening. pros: The Freedom of a fully remote workplace. Working with a kind hearted, decent team of people. I almost never work late or on the weekends. This is a great place to work if you’re a parent. Also the educational opportunities and discounted tuition are a nice plus.
cons: This is a large, old school company that is trying to adapt to change and return to growth. In some ways it is working. We have posted positive numbers and the layoff years are hopefully now behind us. But in other ways University of Phoenix feels like a case study in corporate survival and reluctance to adapt. The company has never really recovered from the 2009-12 era of lawsuits, declining enrollment and bad publicity. I wish I would have known this coming on board. Bringing on George Burnett as CEO in 2022 didn’t help. We needed a leader we could look up to and instead we got a guy with a tarnished reputation who soon resigned. Finally, working in marketing here you walk a fine line between trying to enroll more new students without drawing the ire of state and federal regulators.

pros: Customer-centric is not just a slogan but a mentality. Welfare of employees is top of mind and backed up by actions. Health of the business (financial metrics) is tracked and shared with complete transparency. The consistent message in large meetings and behind closed doors is always, "how can we enhance the quality of student outcomes, ability to improve their careers, etc... if we do that, the financial metrics will take care of themselves." Regardless of your position, your voice matters. I'm sure C-suite titles can be intimidating, but in my presence they have always been humble and interested in other people's opinions and ideas.
cons: There is some bureaucracy and hesitancy to think outside the box. I think most of it is subconscious in that they are so used to doing things a certain way, it's hard to imagine straying too far from the comfort zone. Some hesitancy is likely due to UOPX being held to more scrutiny than other online universities. I 100% believe that UOPX operates very ethically (again, the constant message is "do what's right"). However, I can see where fear might inhibit bold moves.

review_title: Don't Apply to Work for UOPX for 3-5 Years
pros: UOPX does have great benefits and PTO. The current UOPX President was very transparent throughout the changes that happened due to COVID-19.
cons: We often call it "the flavor of the week". Student Services Leadership and UOPX Executive team make so many directional changes and organizational changes that it causes the employees to get disoriented in the whirlwind. For the past year, Operations has been going through the Service Model Redesign. The changes that they make have caused so much added stress on Academic Counselors and have made students express confusion and frustration. I had many opportunities to work closely with Directors and VPs, but once I was no longer needed, it was as if they never even knew me. I strongly advise anyone considering applying to be an Academic Counselor to hold off for 3-5 years. UOPX Leadership needs to figure out what the Academic Counselor will actually be before they start hiring new employees. We had a new Academic Counselor join our team right as COVID-19 forced us to start working from home. This position has so many complexities to it that it was very difficult for her to be successful in the position. She ended up quitting after 3 months. I worked very closely throughout her onboarding to try to be successful, but this job adds so much unnecessary stress on its employees that it is very difficult to stay sane in it. The only solution that UOPX Leadership has implemented to help us with the stress of the position is to download an app called Ginger. At the end of the day, I have been very disappointed in all levels of UOPX Leadership and do not wish my worst enemy to have to work within this company. And I say company because it is not a university. All they care about is making money and not helping students gain an education.

review_title: Past their prime for employment oppurtunnties
pros:
Benefits - Strong PTO with tenure & free school 
The Campus - nice facilities, cafe on site, GYM with classes
Structure & Consistency - The roles are mostly well defined
cons:
They are downsizing. With declining enrollments year after year, they cannot be overstaffed. But it also feels like they are doing a changeover to a new workforce that has lower expectations and subsequently, less ambition. 

They have taken away small perqs like coffee creamer and replace the coffee brand with cardboard. Don't mess with peoples coffee. 

A lot of the leadership in the 2010 era was directors who got to their positions because they could enroll people. Not because they were great business leaders. This had repercussions that were obvious to anyone paying attention.

They rolled out Core Values that later changed when we got a new vendor. How "Core" were these values really?

Medical benefits get worse every single year. 

Advisors with their own teams and students are now working in call centers.  This was not how it was back in the day. It is demoralizing to go from making plans, building partnerships and seeing successes, to transactional interactions.

review_title: Not what it used to be
pros: The Nashville campus has developed an excellent culture in which every employee is valued and treated fairly. We were all on the same page and working towards the same goals. If you have something that you need to discuss with campus leadership, their doors are always open. They listen to their people and make adjustments when necessary. I'm sure that there are other campuses out there with a similar culture.
cons: Unfortunately, senior leadership at the organization can not say the same. The company as a whole is headed in the wrong direction. They aren't listening to their people nor are they compensating them fairly. They are pushing online enrollments an seeing huge dropout rates and ignoring local campus success rates. They say that there is career progression, but it is a broken system and of no value to the organization or its people. Having been a manager at UOP for the past 7 years, I found it  increasingly difficult to keep my team motivated when the organization did nothing to promote career progression. There is little motivation for front line employees to perform beyond the most basic expectations. These are contributing factors as to why they have seen a 40+% decrease in total student enrollment in the past two years.

pros: They pay on time. You do get to teach (which is great if that's what you want to do.)
cons:
Constant interference by management in classroom. I have spent more time teaching than many of these MBAs or MEs (Master's of Education) have been alive -- and who have never actually taught anything, but they constantly bombard me with directives how to teach. The rules regarding academic freedom vary from year to year -- when I started teaching here, the first week was locked in; everything else was left to instructor's discretion; now, I'm being told, nothing in the cookie-cutter curriculum can change. 

I've talked to several instructors who say they have been criticized for critiquing students' work 'too much' (too many comments hurt the students' poor widdle bwains) or too severely. 

The quality of the students is dismal -- I have a class now that is 3rd-4th year students; for some, this is there last class. Their writing is at a 7th grade level -- they either don't care or don't know to even use spell check. Besides that, each class night, half the students leave by the mid-class break (not just me, as I've learned from several other instructors).


It's aggravating to be inundated by propaganda about how first rate the university is. It's just not true. On the one hand, we received a communication exhorting us to academic rigor, and then we have to try to teach from materials produced by the university that have the tone and content that you'd expect directed towards elementary school students.

pros: Great on campus support, classroom has appropriate tools for facilitation
cons: Limited opportunities to teach both on campus and online.

review_title: Great Place to Get Started, Non-Existent for Growth
pros:
+Stable work environment (your shift is your shift, one location, no moving around)
+"Easy" job, managers don't make unreasonable demands or demand high numbers for calls
+Vacation time is front loaded, given 12 days for >1 year, 16 days for 1-3 years, 20 days for 3-7 years, 24 days for 7+ years.
+Able to schedule vacation with little conflict, your lack of presence does not place unnecessary burden on your team
+Management works with employees to train, coach and prepare them. I have yet to see an employee get terminated at the drop of a hat. Or at all for that matter.
+Decent pay, with a raise every year, capping off after 5 years (with new pay scale, as of June 2015)
cons:
-Growth is non-existent. University is downsizing, and with it, management spots are practically unobtainable unless you're already management.
-Mass layoffs happen every few years. As the market for online colleges grow, our customer base diminishes, making excess staff unnecessary. Just the reality of the situation.
-Doing the same thing every day, every week, every month, every year (you get the picture). No variation or professional growth beyond your job

review_title: Has changed over the last few years
pros: Nice culture and benefits are very good.  Education is completely covered aside of reading materials which isn't bad. Can choose your schedule although you do have to have one late day a week and there is a Saturday coverage rotation.  Get to help people make a difference in their life by furthering their education.  Pay is one of the highest among this positions at other schools.  Lots of development!  I feel very prepared to do a lot of things after all the trainings and experiences I have had here.
cons: Told to do one thing but expected to do another: do what is in the best interest of the student but need to enroll many students each month.  Micro managed like crazy: each day must have many dials, hours of talk time, be available for calls, and generate referrals.  You are questioned if one of these is low.  There are even times you have to IM others you are leaving your desk to get coffee or use the restroom.  Must work at least one evening a week and rotate Saturday shifts.  No overtime.  People you talk to on the phone can be very rude and it can be frustrating when students give up for silly reasons or manipulate government funding.

job_title: Senior Enrollment Advisor in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Pros: Good annual salary / paid time off for tenured representatives (5+ years), tuition assistance for graduate degree programs,
cons: Cons: Management's attitude towards employees is "Just be grateful you have a job!" Lack of pay increases or job advancement opportunities for tenured employees, increasingly pathetic benifits (health, dental, vision) package offered every year with reduced coverages and increased costs, stagnant leadership that mostly micromanages trivial details due to lack of clearly defined goals to work towards (a byproduct of government regulation from 2010 that closed the ability of the University to have employee compensation partially based on the number of enrollments that employees generated in a month), a call center work environment and hours, management wants "human, personal" calls with potential clients done in "robotic, mindless" fashion, company operates in a saturated market where every University now offers online degrees, company has remained profitable by cutting personel and operating costs despite dwindling revenue (4.9B in 2010, 4.7B in 2011, 4.3B in 2012, 3.7B in 2013, 3.0 in 2014, and trending towards 2.8B in 2015). The job has gone from what they used to call a "job of choice" to a job for those without a choice.

job_title: Dean, College of Nursing in Phoenix, AZ
pros: UOPX has demonstrated in my short tenure here, that it lives its core values in all areas and around all work. I have served as a leader in Higher Education for many years in primarily public colleges and universities and my experience at UOPX has stood out beyond all others. Often for-profit institutions are criticized as being concerned more about their bottom line than student success or program outcomes. While I expected UOPX to be an institution of integrity and commitment, I did not expect to discover an organization that bravely and courageously acts and operates with a singular focus on creating a positive experience for students. In thirty five years in public CA Community Colleges and CSU's I did not find the kind of intentional effort individually or collectively that delivered on its promise to support students with academic excellence and personal growth.
cons: As with any large organization, the complexity of  systems and processes can present challenges. UOPX has instituted a number of mechanisms and approaches to overcome these hurdles. As a new Phoenix, I have encountered a significant learning curve for navigating these systems and integrating them into the  responsibilities associated with my position.

review_title: They dropped the ball, and put a bad taste in my mouth.
job_title: Adjunct Faculty in San Diego, CA
pros: The four week faculty training session was a positive experience.
cons:
I was applied and went through the interview phase, passed the initial presentation, went through all four weeks of faculty training, audited a class, and then was told that the head of the local school of I.T. would reach out to schedule me to teach my first class.  I waited a few days, then emailed him.  I then waited a few more days and emailed again.  

No one ever reached out to me.  I feel like the faculty members that were doing the training just needed a full class to justify the session so they could get paid out.  I was never told that they did not want to move forward, although it seems they never had any intention on having me facilitate any classes.  I was out gas money, money spent on transcripts and my time (which, as a professional in my field is worth a lot more than I would have been making as a facilitator with University of Phoenix).  

I am saddened to say it, given that I attended University of Phoenix for my undergrad and have long defended the school on social media and elsewhere, but this is the most unprofessional organization I have ever been associated with.

review_title: This job takes advantage of people that are trying to change their lives.....
job_title: Enrollment Advisor in Kansas City, MO
pros: Pay is good for the job. Time off is never an issue. Benifits are good. Enrollment managers and leadership treat employees well. Can be a fun atmosphere.
cons: You have to be okay with not caring about the people you're "helping" and only focused on the bottom line or how many people you enroll for classes. This school hires good people teaches them to manipulate people into enrolling for college if they are ready or not.The majority of the students that attend this school are poor and uneducated. These people are usually eligible for grant money ($5,500), they almost always elect to take out the full amount of loans because the remainder is sent to them. So they get their grant money and end up failing or dropping out. They end up with a large debt and no degree to show for it. The classes are not college level classes. They make them easy so these people will pass and take more classes, which obviously  makes the school more money. The graduation rates for someone that has not been to college before is around 12%. It is a culture dishonesty but everyone acts like they are really helping people when they clearly are not.

job_title: Senior Data Engineer in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Technology stack is evolving. Good talent around and it benefits your professional development.
cons: Not too flexible with telecommuting.

pros: The students were amazing, the one joy of going to work everyday.
cons:
It is a for Profit College.
My opinion is that management from top level on down was so corrupt and dishonest. It was not a healthy work environment.  Employees were worried daily about loosing their jobs to layoff and school closing for good reasons, because there were many of both across the country. The stress of constantly starting new students and retaining current student was horrible. The programs were way overpriced and students were in so much debt from loans they were never going to be able to payoff, and was having a difficult time getting a job after completing their degree.  It was so not worth it, because many companies still considered University of Phoenix to be a diploma mill. Again this is my opinion, I felt that low income especially black students were targeted . I felt the company was extremely  racist and zero opportunity in top upper management positions for blacks. Hopefully  this has changed over the last few years.

pros: Focus on employee development. Commitment to innovation
cons: Lots of change and transition, but that is part of growing.

review_title: Excellence, entrepreneurial spirit with a heart to serve.
pros: They truly serve the students. The team I work with is amazing.
cons: There are no cons to working at the UOPX.

pros: WFH, overtime, flexible shift, benefits,tuition benefits
cons: 65K cap, not much room to advance, healthcare costs

pros: Great team members to work
cons: Not enough classes available for teaching

pros: Learned a lot and family atmosphere
cons: mass layoffs in the end.

pros: Some good, creative, kind people
cons: Everything else. Just not worth it.

pros: Family friendly environment with reasonable accommodations.
cons: Too many changes within the management

job_title: Career Services Advisor in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Great place to work with a great environment to work in.
cons: I don't have any cons for this place of employment

review_title: Great Place to Work, but requires political savviness
job_title: Director of Marketing in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Great benefits and autonomy. Amazing Diversity Groups. Competitive pay
cons: Organization changes, lack in leadership strategy

job_title: Assistant Professor, Mathematics in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Involvement in students work and activities. Beautiful classrooms. I believe University of Phoenix gives the highest priorities to its students' preparedness. The students who graduate from this online University do a lot better in real world and are ready to face the world and start any kind of profession that they have been preparing for. A new facilitator however must have a couple of weeks of online training before he/she can start teaching our classes.
cons: Some part time Faculty like myself might need more courses like may be two different courses because they might have more time at hand.

pros: lots of nice people who work here and really care about students. Nice facilities.
cons:
Most people in enrollment actually believe that they are there to help students. They believe that they are not sales people, like it's a dirty word or something. It's a sales organization and a "for profit" business, just like any other business. It's all about the money. It's ok to do what is best for the student as long as you get them signed up on their first visit. They say there are no "quotas" but there are, without a doubt. Mixed messages from management. Most employees, except for teachers, are 25-35. Two types of sales management-either hands off or hands around your neck.
A good place to work if you don't need any brush up on your computer skills, if you're young and right out of school, if you plan on going for your Masters (which is strongly encouraged) and if you don't want to be promoted. Several people at a time try for promotions which never come. No matter how good you are, you're told that you're too good at what you do in enrollment and you just need a few more years in that position to be ready for a management position.

They have been involved in a lawsuit for unethical practices which is on-going.

pros:
- Work Flexibility
- Awesome team
- Good benefits
cons: - History of issues with upper management but current President/CEO is working hard to improve things

review_title: Happy face on... no matter how much we lie and change.
pros: Enjoyed my coworkers, great pay and good benefits, good management when I was first hired, up front pay structure and promotion process.
cons: At first it was great and I was excited to work there. Over the course of my year there, management changed 3 times. One of those changes was because the manager was trying to pit coworkers against each other and was bad mouthing me to my coworkers. Luckily my coworkers stood up for me and informed upper management. In addition to manager changes, the entire way were expected to do our job changed before we could get a grasp on the previous way. Some of this changing happened with no direct management at all. We were just hoping we were doing it correctly. They also broke up our team and moved some people to other offices that were an hour drive away with out giving much choice, either commute or lose your job. They also did mass layoffs company wide and if that didn't get them under budget, they did mass firings. So if you had a weekness, they found it and used it against you at every turn.

pros: Great people to work with and supervisor was okay
cons: I didn't like the lack of communication. I don't like the bad reputation that UPX has.

pros: This company really care about its staff and how they educate their students.
cons: More in person options needed for students.

review_title: Company is headed in the wrong direction as layoffs continue.
job_title: PC Systems Analyst in Ontario, CA
pros: Good vacation benefits. Vacation days accrued increase the longer you are with the company. The staff that work at the local campuses are great and try their best to make the poor environment more positive.
cons: Pay is at a stand still. No yearly raises. Enrollment is treated the best. IT is treated great if you work in Phoenix, AZ. IT support staff have been all laid off & outsourced with a company based in India. HR is an 1-800 number. You cant talk to a human being in person. Lay offs for this company continue and the company has been in a fiscal downward spiral for the past 6 years. If you are looking for stable employment try looking somewhere else. Layoffs usual happen the following Monday after a graduation ceremony. They force their employees to work graduation on a Saturday with a threat of being written up, then they lay them off on Monday. Real classy!

job_title: Higher Education in San Diego, CA
pros: Excellent pay and benefits, outstanding coworkers
cons: Poor culture with a stressful environment

job_title: Vice President Product Management in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Management team is committed to rebuilding the brand successfully
cons: Siloed departments vs cross functional agile teams

pros:
Good Benefits
Can get degree almost for free
Most of your co-workers are great

I had a lot of really great co-workers and made a lot of great friends.  The work itself is not overly difficult, it is just a matter of learning the academic policies.  I was there almost 7 years, so I went from the metric based pay to the market adjustment pay. Fortunately I was making good money before the new pay structure kicked in.
cons:
No room for advancement
Constant change
Actually implement the management techniques that are taught in class.

There is absolutely no room for advancement.  Moving into other departments is next to impossible because they generally have a person for the job already picked out.  The company is constantly changing and a new student education model is always being introduced.  If you want the company to be a call center, just make it one already.

pros: Great pay, great coworkers who don't understand that for profit education is a scam.
cons: You treat your students like crap. You don't care about them, but only care about them getting into class so the University can make money off of them. High quota of cold calls. Sometimes you're calling people who've been in the database for 10 years and they'll yell out you because obviously, they don't want to be bothered. Some students have had families, have gotten better jobs, and they think of University of Phoenix as a joke. Company has awful values. In training, they told us to focus on quality customer service and that we were not pressured to enroll. When I got back from training, my manager essentially told me to forget the service, don't spend time helping the students, but get them to enroll at all costs, even if they're in debt. I had one potential student who wasn't sure of what she wanted to do or what degree she wanted. My manager listened to the conversation and wanted me to enroll the student in a program that the student didn't express interest towards. Horrible values for a University that doesn't stack up against traditional colleges. The instructors are not all qualified to teach in their subjects, most aren't certified, and the curriculum is not as advanced as they make it out to be. Horrible work/life balance. Unusual shifts. High turnover rate in this position.

review_title: Incredible Place to Go to School, Bad Place to Work
job_title: Senior Enrollment Advisor in Tempe, AZ
pros: Being a University they pay for you to work on your degree. And since this is an online school it's easy to manage work and school with University of Phoenix. This a great place for someone with a bachelors working on a masters to work.
cons: They want a high turn over. They fire those who have been with the company longer and therefore make more money. So even though they have a career plan in which they say you can make a career here, odds are against that happening. Until they pull out of their slump and start growing as a company this is not a safe company to be working for if you want to work there long term.

pros: There is a pretty friendly environment.
cons: Not many options to move up

pros: Good pay and good benefits.
cons: No room for growth. Policies were not very clear. The actual training itself was fine, but the length of training was not long enough. You are left feeling very frustrated and unprepared for the actual job, which can lead to a lot of mistakes if you are not careful. There was not any support after training and you are basically thrown to the wolves and left to figure it out yourself. Many of the internal systems and processes at the time felt very dated/disjointed which lead to a lot of issues and frustration for the advisors and for the students who waited many weeks for their financial aid. A lot of the staff/advisors had been with the company many years and were stubborn/unwilling to change their way of doing things; also makes it extremely hard to get any kind of seniority. Office moral wasn't great. People were unfriendly and there was a lot of "backstabbing". The way the phone systems are set up, if one of your co-workers doesn't answer the phone it will roll to the next available advisor on the team. This is annoying when your co-workers are purposefully ignoring their students phone calls and you get to pick up their slack on top of your own work load.

review_title: A good stepping stone, but there is no career here.
pros: Numerous tutorials and training to personally grow, great employees (but most have left), some tuition covered, comfortable hours.
cons: False sense of upward mobility, lack of communication, poor values that do not align with the actual 'values' and 'morals'.

review_title: Would have been a great position, many years ago
pros:
Pay and benefits seemed to exceed what the actual job duties entailed.
Only in a very few instances you had the sense you were actually making a difference in someone's life by helping them enroll in the university.
I had an excellent front-line manager who treated the job and institution as a university, not just a for-profit organization.
Organization is very responsive to the current regulatory environment and coaches its employees on how to be compliant in their jobs.
cons:
Going through a lot of turmoil and shake-ups at this time.
Job essentially boiled down to a "glorified" call-center position.
A fair number of current and potential students only seem to be enrolled (or interested in enrolling) in school for the financial aid.
Chasing down potential students by phone and email just to see if "they have made any education decisions" gets to be very much like sales, not education.
A highly regulated industry that will have to make significant changes in order to stay relevant.

review_title: A mixed experience, as always, but has some high points
pros:
- The flexibility of online teaching is wonderful (for those who can survive not bumping into colleagues in the office). 
- Many students, even if not all, genuinely need and want an education and believe that UOP can provide it.
- Many of the students require remedial education, making the opportunity to see true advancement in the students a very real possibility.
- Many students report being active military members, making the job have an added layer of service to it.
- There used to be very little flexibility in how/what you could teach. This has improved dramatically, thanks to greater trust in faculty expertise.
- The administration is surprisingly eager to assist faculty, providing pedagogical training, research support, and positive reinforcement messages in web and postal mailings.
cons:
- UOP is not the highest paying online job.
- There is a serious stigma to working for UOP. I have been actively instructed by superior to remove it from my C.V. when going up for promotion elsewhere.
- Contract work requires you wait for "solicitations" for new courses.

pros: Vacation time is very good
cons: No growth, no raises, dead end

pros: The hours are consistent, which is great if you thrive on consistency.  The compensation and benefits are amazing for what you're doing.  Good first sales job.
cons: I absolutely LOATHED working here.  Management is incredibly inflexible when it comes to shifts -- I had to work 11-8 Monday-Friday, which was absolutely horrible since I usually didn't get home until 9PM.  Their expectations for meeting numbers is incredibly unrealistic and shady -- they'll never admit to judging you based on enrollment numbers, but if you're not hitting at least ten enrollments/month they'll want to fire you.  Management is incredibly insensitive and refuses to listen to employee's needs -- people are scared to take off work to take their kids to the doctors.  Don't kid yourself, this is ABSOLUTELY a sales/telemarketing job -- even though the company will never fess up to it in an interview.

pros:
I really like my co-workers and most of them are educated and hard-working. 

I used to love working here! I felt like I was making a difference in the lives of our students and my team was dedicated and we worked together.
cons:
Almost no recognition for a job well done and the only "raise" I've gotten in 2 years is 2% "cost of living". Keep in mind that over the past 2 years my out of pocket cost for benefits has increased so I am actually bringing home less than I did previously. 

The work load for my department has increased to the point that we barely manage to keep our heads above water and our Director keeps adding more to the plate. Our department has changed gears so we are "nameless and faceless" to the students. This has completely taken away any individuality we had.

job_title: Senior Enrollment Advisor in Houston, TX
pros: Each day you get to help students achieve their academic goals. The majority of the students are working adults, parents and non-traditional college aged so they tend to be leery about being in college. As an enrollment advisor you get to help them navigate the enrollment process and encourage them as they transition into college. It can be a rewarding experience.
cons: Where do I begin? The University struggles to put their employees over the stockholder interest. There is no work life balance because you have unusual schedules like Mon-Fri 11-8 or you work Saturdays. You have to earn sick time. Let's say you go out on sick leave to have a baby and exhaust your sick time. You have to earn sick hours with each pay period. I had never heard of such. As an enrollment advisor, you do a lot of cold calling and sometimes yo feel like you work at a call center.  The pay is not comparable to the job and degree requirements. And the company is obsessed with change. Every 3-6 months there is some major change that takes place which shakes the foundation of the company's core.

pros:
Colleagues are great and are willing to lend a hand when asked.
Incentives to team build off campus can break up the day, but do not happen often.
Pay is slightly above poverty line and company provides cost of living increases.
You have air conditioning.
cons: Micro-management at its finest. Managers were hired based upon their previous ability to enroll. Unfortunately, times have changed and students have as well. The company wants to hire quantity over quality and sacrifices the academic value of their programs. The employee morale is the worse and there doesn't seem to be a way to improve their attitudes. In fact, often the thing that gets people through the day is complaining about how poor the company is. University of Phoenix recognizes it has competitors but has done little to stay above the rest. Many managers state that we are the "Mercedes of Education!" I got news for you.... education is not a car.  I would not even recommend to stay at the organization for the educational benefits, the classes are a joke and not a great representation of academic aptitude. I hope fellow colleagues can get out fast! This ship is sinking!!!!

review_title: Great University but Lots of Layoffs
pros:
Most of the people are amazing. Long-term employees care deeply about what they are doing and in helping students achieve their goals of obtaining their college degree. 
They pay really well.
They train for an appropriate amount of time and really teach you how to do your job. 
They have a lot of opportunity for moving around into different positions if you work hard.
cons:
Layoffs are constant and it always feels like you are living on the edge of losing your job. 
There is a definite "good ole boys" mentality and promotions of young males is prevalent.
Pay is not equal between male and female employees doing the same job.
The sales aspect is constantly being "remanaged" and most of the time the newer managers act like they are selling cars - not helping students. Therefore there is a lot of turnover in this area as you cannot sell that way and think you are actually going to be successful in a University environment.

pros: Flexibility with schedule, great time off, okay benefits, autonomy with you operate in your daily work. Because of attrition and lay offs, for the most part you are left with skilled staff and good people to manage.
cons: Senior leadership (VP and up) are completely out of touch. There is no recognition for hard work or being a top performing team, you are consistently told it is not enough. No/little support from directors as their job seems more operational than management. Consistently focused on who needs to go, little recognition, if any for top performing reps. Many promises and little follow through. There’s no incentives. High, high pressure to perform but not even a solid recognition program to value people.

pros: As everyone mentions- discounts for employees to attend their programs-- but this is any institution of higher education so it is nothing special.
cons: In any other university, professors are encouraged to help coach students to find a career path that will be most fulfilling and rewarding whether that be fiscal or more internal. At UoP, one has to be cautious to ensure such coaching only is within the programs they offer lest your evaluations suddenly shift. Even with great evaluations, course offerings are inconsistent and the instruction is prescribed and as a for-profit, their are students who are paying for programs for which their background would prevent them from entering the field that UoP was more than happy to allow them to take out student loans to fund the courses for which they were also ill-equipped to enter. Huge focus on upper management negates the quality of instruction. Other professors have advised that I remove this experience from my CV as it is not a respected program in the higher education community.

review_title: Rewarding Experiences but not the Pay
pros:
- Rewarding feeling from helping advance the lives & careers of working adults. 
- Generally a supportive environment for new ideas, developments, and advancements. 
- Free tuition for degree & certificate programs as well as individual classes. 
- Wide range of benefits to choose from to match medical & budget needs.
cons:
- Pay for skilled work is considerably lower than market while entry-level is at or above market in most cases. 
- Limited opportunity for advancement beyond mid-level roles. 
- Advancement of roles, projects, and career tends to be heavily driven by politics (you can lose a promotion to a lesser skilled/tenured employee simply over 'friends' network). 
- Very difficult to get significant raises despite performance or accomplishments; mostly 3% or less with 4% being max (and rare) of which a portion is taken by consistent benefits cost increases. 
- The availability of the great benefits comes at significant cost to employees.

review_title: If you need your masters degree (without having to pay for it) then Phoenix is  for you.
job_title: Enrollment Advisor in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Hmm....well they do offer tuition benefits for their own degree programs. This is a fair benefit and it is a major reason why many of the employees stay with the company.  By the way....it is a for profit company....do not think you will be working for a traditional university.  Phoenix is focused on the consumer student.  Most of the students are motivated to earn a degree for financial reasons.  This is  not a research institution and the student body is just looking for a "ticket" for a better job or a raise.  There is nothing wrong with that....you just have to  get used to that mindset.
cons: Basically, this is a family owned company.  The publicly traded stock has no voting rights to elect members of the board.  This results in the classic "top down" management style with all the problems that go with it.

review_title: They talk the talk, but don't expect them to walk the walk
pros: They care about students and higher education goals more than other for-profit institutions and the technology they offer students is top notch.  They also offer education benefits to students.  100% for a bachelor's degree and $5250[industry standard]/year for a master's.
cons: Management will not care about you, only what you can produce for them.  Though this isn't a sales job, it will feel like one and the students are first, second, third, etc.  Employees are not important and treated like replaceable warm bodies although they have it in their mission to be a career of choice - what a contradiction to the environment they create for their employees!

review_title: Great benefits, professional management, wonderful benefits. Salary (not hourly)+overtime pay.
job_title: Student Services Coordinator in Columbia, MD
pros: Raises are annual base on percentage 1% to 5% based on performance. No need to clock-in/out. Managers don't make you feel guilty for calling in sick, 5 weeks on vacation annually...WOW! Trusting non-micromanagers. Therefore, I never feel like I'm walking on eggshells. Observes 10 paid holidays.Fair treatment of employees in the Student Services department. Great benefits. Flexible scheduling. Not a whole lot of politics in this dept. Stability in Student Services dept. Professional and helpful team of coworkers and managers. We are treated with respect.
cons: They want the best employees for LOW pay. Expect priceless benefits like positive culture but don't expect competitive pay. UOP pays employees below market salary rate. Growth in the Bay Area is so competitive that you will likely have to relocate in order to grow. Student Services Coordinator position is under a glass ceiling which hinders promotional growth. That is, unless you have a close relationship with hiring manager. "kissing butt" is required to move up in the company.

review_title: If you don't mind talking a lot, this job is pretty good.
pros:
Attend classes at University of Phoenix free of charge (awesome perk).
No micromanaging as long as you are working hard.
You get to determine your game plan for the day without much interference.
You can put your feet up on your desk, walk around, bounce a ball off the wall, etc. (as long as you stay on the phone).
You can take your lunch break pretty much whenever you want.
Cafeteria and gym on site at the Phoenix location.
Manager was very cool and let me alter my work schedule when needed.
Chances for lateral and vertical moves within the company.
cons:
Lots of outbound calling to leads that have already been called countless times.
Receive many inbound calls from people who are terrible candidates for an expensive online education.
Too many meetings.
Not for the faint of heart - you will talk to some grouchy folks from time to time.
Being on the phone so much can be a grind sometimes.
Company was in a state of flux and confusion following the the GAO investigation (might be better now, though).

pros: Working for the University of Phoenix is a great way to enhance a professional career, while helping students seeking to establish a career or change career directions. Adjunct facilitators are typically professionals who have worked in their fields for several years, who have the advantage of sharing their experiences with students. Due to the culture of the university, facilitators also get an opportunity to learn from students.  Intensive and useful orientation training and a mentorship is provided prior to entering the classroom. Classes are setup and managed online. Classes are facilitated in person or online. Facilitators are paid per contract, with more than 50% of the pay being issued after the first class and the remaining after the last class is completed. The school provides a wealth of resources for its staff and students, including career development workshops, professional opportunity leads, and information about the latest developments in various careers.
cons: Most of the faculty are adjunct. Very few full time positions are available. Several learning centers will close. This will be a con for those who wish to facilitate classes in person.  However, more opportunities may be available for online staff.

pros: A beautiful place to work with a nice total rewards package. Many opportunities for interdepartmental advancement up to lower level management.  Great programs for exploring different skills within in the university outside your chosen career field. Great inclusion of experience at all levels for innovative projects (SMEs and frontline staff to AVPs).  Transparency and communication are very excellent.
cons: Culture in theory is excellent but in practice is poor.  Little oversight by executive leadership on senior leadership.  Extremely poor social setting, with heavy politics and jockeying for position.  Although UoP is an industry leader in online education they lack innovation in recent years.  In addition, organizational and business strategy is constantly changing which is very tumultuous.  Although change is good, this organization fails to allow enough time to determine if change is successful before moving quickly to the next approach.  Gainful employment has taken a huge toll on for profit industry and this particular business is in decline.

review_title: Great company to work for but little opportunity for growth
job_title: Senior Finance Advisor in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Great pay, good benefits, I enjoy the opportunities I have for problem solving,
cons: There is almost no opportunity for growth. Every time a new position opens, it is closed immediately or turned into a lateral move. Many employees waste time all day and others are left to pick up the slack. Employees are not disciplined for slacking off. Pay is based on tenure not the value of the work done (however, the pay is good). I would prefer to be paid based on what I do so that the person doing nothing next to me is not paid the same. The company needs to learn to fire employees who have stopped working hard for it. Most of middle management is unreliable. It is amazing how many managers call in sick all the time.

pros: Personally, I think the load would be much easier if you were in Enrollment, or Academic. Being a Finance Advisor/Counselor is quite discerning and yet has its rewards. It is a customer service experience that you are gaining, but your also gaining experience in the field of finance which is beneficial. You do have a team and as long as the team can work together and see eye to eye then all will be well. They have frequent team-builders and volunteering which is a must a UOPhx. There are also great benefits.
cons:
Talking about money to a student can be like talking to a brick wall and if that student has failed a class be prepared to have that wall blow up in your face. 
Work/life does need be worked on a little, they tend to forget that people do have lives outside of work. 
Everything is based off of numbers, not service so it can feel like they are treating you like a number and not an employee. 
There does seem to be a competition between all the advisors. Again, it's all about numbers.

pros: Great place to be trained as faculty.  Offers educational opportunities for those who want to begin teaching.
cons: As a long time employee of University of Phoenix, I would tell those interested in teaching at University of Phoenix to be careful about working for the organization. It was an excellent place to work years ago. However, recently the organization has gone through some tough economic challenges, and it has been investigated by the government over the past five years for some academic issues. The organization came through the process okay, but the number of students has decreased based on the bad publicity. The pay rate has been stagnant for faculty throughout this time frame. Then, the organization decided to either cut back on faculty classes or dismiss various faculty members without warning or cause. If you want a steady income from an organization, I would consider working somewhere else as the faculty members will be used if needed but dismissed for no cause if that is best for University of Phoenix.

review_title: Good experience but NO way to move up!
pros: Good experience when you have a good manager. I was lucky enough to have a hand full of good managers a few great one. I gained great experience there through professional development classes and on the job training. I really appreciated the benefit of free school. It is a really wonderful perk of the job!
cons:
On the other hand if you have a terrible manager that has a huge ego then you have not chance of moving up or even learning new skills. This University has a problem with promoting people that are good at their job but have no management or people skills. Manager training is very important and this University  doesn't seem to value that. 
They also take advantage of their good managers and do not compensate them properly for excelling in their roll.
This university also has a problem with communication; they don't seem to think their employees are smart enough to handle honest communication.

review_title: Asked to be a sales person and not a counselor
pros:
Best reason to work for University of Phoenix- Education Benefits for self and family.
Very good health care package- not the best I have ever had, but good enough in comparison to other packages offered by competitors.
cons: The biggest downside to working at University of Phoenix is the Big Brother aspect.  They track everything, every bathroom break, time you clock in, number of times you call a particular student, what was said on the phone to students, ect.  Everything was monitored and they did not approve of individual thought and creativity because they are formula driven.  All conversations should lead to a closing of potential students Not a Positive working environment, lots of negative energy in a place that is supposed to inspire others to new heights.

review_title: No Promotion Opportunities/No Longer A Student Focused Organization
job_title: Senior Academic Counselor in Phoenix, AZ
pros: The people and students you work with.  Weekends off.
cons: One wrong Manager can undermine the great efforts HR puts forth to hire great talents for the Academic Counselor position.  Perhaps some of these Managers interviewed well, but when in the position it is recognized that the Manager has no interpersonal communication skills or tact.  After 5 years of great experiences with 5 different Managers, one organizational change had me paired up with a Manager that clearly didn't like people of a different background than theirs.  There's a lot of reinventing the wheel at this organization.  Often times the change was reversed and we went back to square one with the way we service students.  If it isn't broke, don't fix it.  How about continue investing in the classrooms and student experience instead.  I would steer clear and maybe look at Maricopa Colleges, Grand Canyon University or ASU.  Pay increases at UOP are based on the for-profit school market share salaries, so the increase isn't much.  I am still in touch with all my former team members and other employees and after a year or more of not working there, it's still the same and layoffs are still happening.  Not a stable career.

pros: Training is great, starting salary is decent. The company is massive so if you are a top performer you can get promoted very quickly. This is especially the case if you are willing to relocate. I work at a medium sized campus, so getting to manager within a year is not uncommon for top performers.
cons: Salary is low if you are a top performer with where you can get else where. You cannot make direct commission due to department of education guidelines. You also do not receive bonuses. If you want to make larger amounts of money you will have to move into management. A top performer EC will earn around 41-50k after one year of work. You will have your pay adjusted every six months for performance, this is when you get your raises.

review_title: Fun atmosphere, but long hours and INTENSE demands
pros:
1.  Fun atmosphere (sometimes they put on fun forums, luncheons, etc)
2.  Praised if you performing well
3. Training dept is AWESOME! They really prep you for such an intense job
cons:
1. LONG hours (44 hours/weeks = 10 M-Th and 4 hours Friday or Saturday)
2. Sometimes have to work Saturdays
3. Sales job.  You have to make 100 calls/days and have to enroll students to go to the University
4. In order to get benefits, you have to wait 90 days after you're on permanent hire with the company. AND in order for you to become permanent, you have to go to through a month's training...go to your assigned campus (which is typically your choice) and work there for two months...and if you enroll 4 students for those two months, you will be CONSIDERED for permanent hire.  It takes the average enrollment counselor SIX months to receive benefits.

review_title: Was once an innovator, now struggling to maintain relevance.
pros: Initially the benefits were amazing and yearly salary increases made it a job of choice and some leaders/managers had integrity and honest intentions.  When news of secret recruitment tactics began to emerge and the value of the degree questioned, the UoP ship lost its rudder. Benefits have been cut drastically recently from what I've heard.
cons: Inconsistency in enforcement of company policies, too many associate directors and other middle management who openly played favorites and despite abandoning the "matrix," enrollmemt numbers and other numbers were simply tied to competencies or whatever flavor of the quarter management came up with to keep everyone drinking the kool-aid. Worse is the constant looming threat of layoffs or a write-up which is a one way ticket to termination.

pros: The good is that if you can hit the ground running and 'get it' right away you can get a good pay increase in just six months. Co-workers tend to be pretty cool, fun to be around. . The ugly of it is simply the randomness of favoritism that goes on there. Someone who hits double their goal might get a plaque but then someone who barely makes it might get sent to California or Chicago on the companies dime as a reward. Can't really explain that but that's how it was.
cons: The bad is that occasionally morlocks come up and snatch the fun loving eloy (sorry if have that backwards, haven't read that book since high school, but you get the idea). I guess what I mean is that sometimes there is an internal panic about not hitting a goal and then the sh*t hits the fan for a little while

review_title: Dysfunctional work environment and incompetent management.
pros: Tuition assistance and a good life/work balance. Your vacations days are fronted to you, healthcare premiums are reasonably priced and you can easily flex your work schedule.
cons: Not sure if I have enough room for all the cons. Stay away unless you like to be miserable everyday. People don't work well together there probably because the management is completely incompetent. Many managers were promoted during the boom time, degree mill days, several years ago and have no experience and little education. The reviews before mine are so true. You will never get promoted and the pay sucks. It's less than the median for this job and way less than the national average income/salary. Can't believe I waste 2 years of my life there but I earned a MBA (for what it's worth) and was lucky to be employed during the recession.

job_title: Adjunct Online Instructor in Phoenix, AZ
pros:
Asynchronous classroom works with my schedule
Can work from home
Has improved their learning materials greatly
Offers opportunities to interact with other faculty members online and in person
Offers opportunities to improve one's teaching skills
cons:
In trying to keep student enrollment high, the school has created even more work for faculty.
Heavy workload of one paper per student per week, plus interacting in class. This may work for someone who teaches all the time, but not for someone who has a job outside academia.
Many students' work is not on a college level. Many students' writing level is such that reviewing papers is a chore. Instead of gaining insight into students' thoughts on the subject, I find myself concentrating on spelling, grammar and organization. And most of my students are about to graduate!

review_title: Great place to work at, awesome enviroment.
pros:
Lots of resources to train for your position. Flexible work hours and schedule. Fair Compensation.  Accessible communication with upper management and free tuition if you attend University of Phoenix! 
My co-workers are really friendly and approachable always ready to teach me without feeling like I'm a burden. I love the work culture and support from upper management. I was given the option to work from home during the Covid-19 pandemic and they are giving me my entire work hours!
cons: HR department is all the way in Phoenix, sometimes there's delay in communication with local manager and HR.

review_title: Hard to leave, but wanted to many times
job_title: Senior Re-entry Representative in Gardner, KS
pros: Great pay and increases combined with very strong benefits makes University of Phoenix a job that provides for it employees a lot of incentive to stay.  It makes it very hard to leave when you are paid well above the average and want to stay in the same career path.
cons: Lack of Honesty from top down.  Direct managers are typically trustworthy to their word but that is because they are not provided any real update on what is going on in the company.  They have no real power for change and no say in how things go down.  They are blindsided as well as anyone else when something comes down the pipe.

review_title: Worst sales enviornment of my 36 years in sales
pros: Can make really good money if you don't mind screwing over people less fortunate than you.
cons: Brutal environment....think GlenGary GlenRoss.  New leads are for "closers". If you do not take advantage of very vulnerable applicants you will fail.  If you really care about people, and attempt to give them the information so they can make an informed choice about what is best for them, you will get squeezed out. They will stop giving you "hot" new leads and only give you old leads that the top sales people were unable to close. So, guess what, then you sales get worse and worse until they use that as an excuse to let you go. You are encouraged to financially ruin people with very few resources in order to pad your own (and thereby the company's)  pockets.  It's an environment that turns even good people into selfish, ruthless salespeople. Those who come in with that mentality can be very successful. Those that have a sense of personal integrity do not last.

job_title: Senior Enrollment Representative in Owings Mills, MD
pros: The best organization I have ever worked for, they really cared about the people who they employed, they also had the best training in sales and marketing that I have ever seen any company to have. The people there were very professional and caring and the job opportunities were endless. The education was outstanding and I could only hope to work for another organization such as the University of Phoenix.
cons: After the Founder died the University begin to fall apart and now it has a lot of political battles in which I think that it can overcome but does not want to no longer fight. The University of Phoenix has touched so many lives both academically and professionally and I hate to see such a great educational institution fade away. It learning model has been revolutionary in touching the lives of every day working adults and its legacy shall live on.

job_title: Executive Enrollment Advisor in Phoenix, AZ
pros:
Offers above average healthcare benefits
Pays for undergrad degree and portion of graduate degrees for employees
Great product, talk and work with people who want to change their lives through education
Have a gym on site
cons:
Most of their talented employees don't want to promote due to lack of compensation for managers (they can make much more as and adviser) which results in the company having bad management.
Constant change in compensation, leadership, performance appraisals, etc. 
Promote based on "competencies" a.k.a "who you know", rather than actual performance data.
I have been there 7 years and have exceeded any performance expectation they have given me, yet they are now making me work Sat and Sun. Basically tenure/performance means nothing, again its about who you know.
Company is declining, no promotion opportunities.
Company recently moved all workers from salary/independent workers to hourly/call center/micro managed mode

review_title: Big on advertising poor on execution.
pros: University of Phoenix or its parent company Apollo Group Inc. is always looking for fresh talent which is strength. Additionally with the companies tuition discount they are looking to improve their employees current knowledge base at all times.
cons: Unfortunately, University of Phoenix as well as Apollo Group Inc. are publicly traded companies and therefore are for profit entities and have to use that model when they look not only at their employees but their students as well. This is an organization with no true direction and pushes new products out as fast as possible just to see if they will stick. Then when the bottom line is affected the employees are the first to be downsized quickly followed buy yearly rate hikes on tuition for students.

job_title: Veterans Affairs Representative in Phoenix, AZ
pros:
Wonderful benefits. Pays for school which is a plus! Also 4 weeks of paid leave and having most holidays off is another perk!

Pot lucks, mandatory fun days (go to baseball games, bowling, pizza days.. )
cons: People getting promoted under the good ol boy system. There was a girl who got promoted over more qualified and tenured individuals - she walked into the interview wearing flip flops. Office drama - there should be a reality show. Policies are always changing so have to get used to that. Not too many availabilities for promotions. The pay starts at 26K/Yr and based on performance you can get an increase every year (maybe by 1k if your lucky). You do a lot of work but it does not pay what you deserve.

review_title: Disappointed--From okay, to bad, to worse
pros: Awesome product, that is online education. Small classroom size, actual professors that teach in the fields they work, staff that genuinely cares for their students.
cons: Extremely poor leadership, very inept management, no opportunity for growth. The company is shrinking because they operated under a flawed model for way too long. They don't promote anymore, and when they did promote you better be both young and good looking. It all about style over substance.

job_title: Senior Enrollment Representative in Phoenix, AZ
pros: In my opinion the staff for the College of  Humanities and Social Sciences created a positive environment and wrte committed to the students and their success. The benefits were incredible until last year when UOP decided against being self insured due to ACA (Obamacare)and joined forces with other corporations to save money therefore cost for employees went up and coverage went down. (Like many corporations)
cons: In my opinion, since 2010 when ACA was passed, instead of focusing on healthcare, education was wrapped up in the middle of the bill and a bullseye stamped on its back causing unintentional consequences. The trickle down affect forced upper management to chase it's tail instead of focusing on the student and their core beliefs.  Over the years many layoffs have occurred, very stressful not knowing when you would be handed a box without a clear distinction of criteria.

job_title: Online Adjunct Faculty in Big Rock, IL
pros: You teach courses in an online environment, so you have lots of flexibility.  This is a good part-time job for making extra money.
cons: Often, many of the students were under-prepared and lacked the ability to write a grammatically correct, coherent five-paragraph essay.  It made it very difficult to teach course content because I was spending more time deciphering poorly written papers. Also, I had to re-write and clarify poorly written curriculum, discussion questions, etc. that we were required to use by the curriculum developers.  Finally, instructors are not evaluated on the quality of their instruction, learning materials, or feedback, but on the frequency of the feedback.  If an instructor misses their feedback frequency goal, they are subject to go through a two or three week training review.

pros: Great coworkers. Good benefits and work-life balance. Dress code comfortable and casual. Vacation and holiday time was above average. Easy commute.
cons: Severe micro-management. Diversity and/or autonomy nonexistent. Saturday and evenings required periodically. Job itself was tedious. Sales position with sparse and outdated leads. Expected to function in a sales capacity without the bonus or incentive pay. Lack of consistent communication from the top down. Procedures changed on a dime leaving us unclear about how we should perform our jobs. Performance under microscope every minute of the day and 99% of feedback focused on the negative. No advancement opportunities. Huge pay disparity between people transferring and those who had been in position at my location.

pros: Most of the time, everyone is welcoming, they show a growth mindset where they see adversities as opportunities, and help you move forward with a teaching  experience. We are trained as coaches and out main goal is to empower our students to learn to coach themselves once they have graduated. Benefits are great and managers are very understanding of you situation, if you ever encounter one.
cons: Workload is heavy, you never seem to be caught up with it and you need to learn to manage your time effectively, and to understand that workload will be heavy but we work as a team so everyone will assist you if you need help. Getting organized comes with time and managers are very helpful and want you to be successful so they create coaching plans with you to learn how they can best support you. .

review_title: Another shady school...Hope others look elsewhere!
job_title: Online Enrollment Advisor in Chandler, AZ
pros: In the past, you were able to make very good money, just by enrolling students into the school.  You can go to the school for free, or pay very little towards your masters.
cons: New hires or anyone hired past 2008 will not be making very much money.  The students are getting worse, most just signing up to get a pell cheque, and will drop once they get their first disbursement.  The school doesn't have a nursing program, yet in the healthcare program I was mainly taking nursing calls!  I spent half my time explaining why these potential students couldn't be a nurse and should settle for an associates in administration.  The job is totally depressing and stressful.  Also, if you are in the Arizona area, be prepared to work with the most superficial people who just talk about their body image and weight issues all day.  The place is total chaos!

pros: University of Phoenix has changed a lot since I first started working there.  The benefits of working there include great salaries, fun working environment and great benefits (including tuition benefits).  I worked at multiple locations at University of Phoenix and really enjoyed the people I worked with for the most part.
cons: In the most recent years, the university has changed.  With the decrease in performance over the past few years, there are more and more layoffs that happen.  The university is really shifting its focus to attracting a new type of student which is great, but also it impacts many employees because there is not as much demand.  There is constant fear of layoffs which is not a fun environment to work in.

pros: During my entire 6 year tenure there were professional development opportunities offered for no additional cost in addition to certifications and bachelor's and master's for free. As the company downsized those became less and less but in the beginning, there was an amazing amount of webinars, and training available for managers and employees alike. Communication was as transparent as possible from the top down, however not timely. It was encouraged to sit in on shareholders calls quarterly to learn how we impacted the business.
cons: Timeliness of communication about downsizing, culture went extremely downhill in times of ambiguity and downsizing, management training became non existent and professional development opportunities disappeared. Typical remote campus issues.

review_title: This position is about one thing only, how many people can you sign up.
pros: Free education until Graduate program, then significant savings. If yor goal is to obtain an education while you work at UOP it is a great choice. The benefit package is excellent and reasonably priced as well. The company takes good care of employees from a benefits standpoint.
cons: The mid-level managers are very inexperienced and offer no significant coachng abilities or assistance with career growth. The managers focus on the number of students more than the quality of the students being admitted to the program. The position is more comparable to a sales call center than an advisory role.

pros: I have been with this company for 7 years, I love the compensation and benefits. There is free tuition offered to employees so I was able to obtain my Bachelors Degree for free. Healthcare options are out of this world, advanced vacation time for the year, paid holidays. I have enjoyed all the mangers I have worked with over the 7 years.
cons: This company is crumbling fast. There are several rounds of layoffs every year, you always feel on edge and there is job uncertainty. The grey cloud hanging over the company is creating bad attitudes among employees. There is no room for growth, & you max out on pay. Upper management racks in the dough doing little work, while the small people work their tails off to keep students enrolled and get stuck on the chopping block. There is way to much change at this company and its not a fin place to work any longer.

review_title: Looks like a good opportunity from the outside, but there is a total lack of respect for new Instructors
job_title: Instructor in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The classes are at night and this makes taking on classes easy for professionals.  UOPHX has its own training program and so teaching degrees are not required. The format is very wired and the modules are pre-set, which tends to move the thoroughput in an organized and efficient manner.
cons: New Instructors are given mentors and lists of classes they can teach.  When classes approach, however, you are bumped out of your class if someone else desires to teach it or wants to expand their load. This results in you preparing for days without ultimately being paid.  UOPHX never shows the respect they demand, and higher Management commonly lies to "smooth things over".

review_title: Very stressful, a glorified telemarketing operation that does not value their students.
job_title: Online Academic Advisor in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Pros are friendly colleagues (not management), free college tuition, reasonable pay, and good health insurance.
cons: Very stressful environment.  Management makes constant changes and does not care about the rapport with students that you have built up.  Often the changes have a negative effect on the student experience- like changing degree requirements in the middle of a student's program and necessitating an appeal to have this corrected (lots of extra work). You are "judged" based on your call lengths, computer generated tasks completed, and ineffective call campaigns.  The running joke is "What does management do?"  They are not present in assisting their teams solve their problems and show little regard for solving issues that affect both employees' and students' experience.

review_title: Seems promising at first, but no good deed goes unpunished in Faculty Services Dept
pros: Tuition benefits, flexible work schedule, comfortable work environment (i.e. new building), health and wellness initiatives
cons: Emphasizes "good attitude" over work ethic -- which means lousy workers are promoted because they are perky and obedient while those pulling the most weight are left behind because they ask too many questions and know how to think critically. Organization is top heavy -- promotes directors into positions that did not exist for higher pay brackets directly after a layoffs. Zero project management skills. Refuses to take feedback (even when asking for it during 360 reviews) and avoids all conflicts.

review_title: Used to be forward thinking - market caught up, and is now just reactionary
job_title: Senior Enrollment Advisor in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Great benefits, nationwide network opens more opportunities (although there is stigma attached to those trying to move from online services to campus services and vice-versa). Provides valuable service (albeit overpriced). Many great people to work with. The people make it a great place, the organization seems to do all it can to stifle that though.
cons: Untrained management from the bottom up to the top. Managers, Directors, VPs, and Execs all advanced based on performance, not on management skills. Company consistently takes top producers off the floor and moves them into management even when that is not the best use of that persons skills. Consistently underpays - touts "total package/value is greater" - just pay your people for the work they do.

pros: The best thing (maybe only thing) about working at UOP is the vacation/benefits. Definitely the most generous thing they give and a huge reason why they keep people. If they did not offer this, people would jump ship way more often.
cons: This list is huge - pay not always commensurate with each job, immature lower level management and downright unethical senior management. CONSTANT change at every level on almost everything in the company. You can never get to a comfortable level with your job before they change it all up again. Highly unethical company. The stuff I saw was not ok. The lawsuits of the past were well justified.  Almost no advance possible. Spent about 9 years in the same low level job because it was nothing but layoffs and no job openings. Constant cost cutting that never ends, getting cheaper and cheaper. The list goes on....

review_title: Don't become complacent because of vacation hours and a paycheck.
job_title: Senior Finance Advisor in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Vacation time is what keeps most people at this job.  Pay is decent, but don't let that cloud your judgment.
cons: If you like working in the same job for the rest of your life with no career advancement then you will like this job.  If working to only satisfy a paycheck and forgoing any self worth or values is in your vocabulary, please do apply.  If you like indebting people with student loans or sending people to collections please do apply.  If you have an ear for being yelled at and like dealing with escalated issues on a consistent basis please do apply.  There are better jobs out there and better places to work that do not challenge your integrity and morals.

pros: The majority of the people I worked with were kind, wonderful people who cared about their students and wanted everyone to succeed.
cons: They continually say that they are not about the numbers of students you enroll, but about the quality of student you enroll, but if you do not enroll the number of students they deem necessary, you take a hit, or you are terminated. The leads I was given are mostly years-old, over worked,  and not valid. Incoming leads are typically for students who are wanting nursing degree programs that UoP did not offer or could not offer. The location of the campus is also really inconvenient for a lot of people (inaccessible by bus route for those without cars).

review_title: Frustrating with too many layers, politics and incompetent managers.
pros: The pay, benefits and professional development are the only reasons to work there along with the relaxed atmosphere where it seems there is no accountability for actually working.
cons: I would not recommend this place for someone who is motivated, competent or looking to bring innovation to the workplace. There is too many layers, politics and conflicts of interest between outside companies and the internal departments. When there were layoffs and cutbacks of employees they were still overspending on ineffective marketing, expensive sports partnerships, paying huge salaries to friends and business partners of VPs and Presidents.

review_title: Put Students First  and Learn to Play the Game and You'll Be Fine
job_title: Mid-Level Manager in Diamond Bar, CA
pros: Most staff and students are awesome to work with and if you stay open to it you can really watch people grow on a daily basis. Tuition reimbursement is never a bad thing and you can definitely work full-time and go to school.
cons: If you don't adapt well to constant change this is probably not the place for you.

review_title: If you don't drink the Kool-Aid, be warned!!
pros:
The pay was reasonable compared to the work - its not hard to dial a phone!
If you are currently pursuing your degree at UOP, they will pay 100% of your tuition...but it still doesn't make it worth it!
cons: The managers were not leaders, they were better salespeople than you. The atmosphere of the company was to get as many students enrolled as possible, which isn't always in the best interest of the students, which is a big part of why I left. The offices were very "clicky" and quite honestly, I'm too far removed from high school to deal with that. Also, management "highly recommended" (read: twist your arm like only your mom can do) OT to get ahead but would hold it against you if you only worked 40 hours a week.

review_title: It was a great place to work; however, it seemed that people "dropped like flies" unexpectedly!
pros: They promote personal development and continued education.  They also try to give employees recognition and praise for everything.  You can get a degree for (almost) free!  The training is great and the computer systems are user-friendly. They appreciate creative ideas; even if they don't implement them.
cons: Retention goals at times are nearly impossible to attain.  Your hours correspond with your students.  Ie, you will probably work until 6 or 7pm so you can give welcome presentations and reach students outside of their normal working hours.  Because it is a private university, changes can happen rapidly and unexpectedly.  One day you have a job that you love; the next day you don't.

review_title: Good company to work for with good benefits
pros: University of Phoenix is a great employer. It is a steady job and offers good benefits including education. As an employee you are always busy and most managers are open. The company is going through some changes but I believe they have the best intentions in mind. Is the original online university and is still the best because they do for the most part keep the student in mind.
cons: Make your message more clear. Stop changing things every 5 seconds and truely be open to advice from your employees. You have a Very educated staff and many resources at your fingertips which you could utilize to your benefit.

job_title: Senior Finance Advisor in Phoenix, AZ
pros: PTO, Good work life balance
cons: Middle Management complacent and slow to react to escalated issues.  No opportunities for career advancement.  The job you are hired in at will be your job throughout the remainder or your employment.  Raises are not based on performance and provides for lazy individuals to continue being lazy.  No incentive to individuals that are top performers and willing to go above and beyond.

review_title: Enjoyed my time at University of Phoenix
pros: Great training and wonderful people to work with. University of Phoenix promotes team work offering many different events through out the year to break up your work day. This company believes in giving back to the community, they also offer very good benefits.
cons: For this position you must enjoy phone work.
