This was difficult for me as I would start at 7 am in the morning and although I would consider myself a happy morning person, that did not necessarily cross over into wanting to talk on the phone that early. This company is also continually changing, so if you can't handle change you may want to look else where for employment.

job_title: Senior New Student Advisor in South Phoenix, AZ
pros: The salary and benefits. We get paid extremely well for what we do. The benefits are also unmatched with any other company I've been with. No take home work - a briefcase free job. Drama free environment, everybody is very professional.
cons: The company is coming up out of a recession in enrollment. They are trying to save costs and therefore are only hiring on an as needed basis. If you're looking for upward career mobility, you won't find it here. You have to work a 45 hour work week (lunches are a one hour extension of your day). Shifts are determined by seniority; if you're a newcomer, expect to work 9am-6pm or possibly even a 10am-7pm shift.

pros: The job pays well if you have a bachelors degree.  The company pays for your education.
cons:
The departments are understaffed and change is constant.  Too many changes at once can cause confusion and inconsistency within all departments.  Also, upper management should do a better job about communication how and when the changes will be implemented.  So many times we get emails saying change X effective yesterday or today.  This does not give us enough time to become familiar with changes to inform students as they call during the day.  
Also, the workload is unmanageable for the majority of staff and students become escalated on a regular bases due to lack of contact from their assigned advisor.   Calls a a priority and the rest the work responsibilities get put on the back burner.

pros: competitive salary, continuous challenges, and ability to help educate people that otherwise would not have the opportunity to further their education.
cons: Goals that are not clearly expressed yet held accountable to.  The goals that are established are a round about way to increase enrollment. Pressure from upper management regarding these unclear goals.  you never know own when you areceive doing good enough and when doing well it is only good for today.  there is a what are you going to do for me tomorrow mentality.  there is also no room for growth.  the company is shrinking and at this point you are lucky to just hang onto your job.

review_title: Students not prepared - they can "buy" their way
job_title: Adjunct Online Instructor in Tucson, AZ
pros: Flexibility of being able to work from anywhere. UOPX is good at providing faculty training.
cons: Students are woefully unprepared for the rigors of grad school. Most write at a middle school level. How did they graduate high school AND undergrad?? To compound the problem, all of the textbook answer keys are for sale everywhere as are essays and papers. The plagiarism is rampant and I spend too much time verifying the legitimacy of submissions and grading illiterate assignments than actually teaching the subject. And the students don't care - I've "busted" students for blatantly cheating only to have them continue cheating week after week because UOPX only gives them a slap on the wrist while chastising faculty for grading too hard. Do you want academic rigor or not? There are a lot of very qualified professionals working for peanuts to improve the lives of others. Recognize them for what they contribute.

review_title: Appreciate the flexibility but want more advanced curriculum and more proficient students
pros: Flexibility of work hours (adjunct faculty online). Accountability of faculty and students to a criteria system (number of posts per day, etc.). Online classroom discussion forum. Resources (library journal subscriptions). Most syllabus, assignments, readings, etc. were already established. Flexibility in choosing which classes to take. Classes are only 5 weeks.
cons: Lots of confusion about who is in charge of modifications to curriculum and course changes. Very frustrating lack of notification of course changes. Very poor handling of cancellation of courses (lack of notification until day class begins). Very political nature of emails to staff, soliciting staff to contact legislators, in regards to recent push for regulation of for-profit colleges.

review_title: Company is having difficulty finding their footing again.
job_title: Senior Enrollment Advisor in Little Rock, AR
pros: Excellent training, strong culture. Open door policy is pretty genuine, bottom-up transparency encouraged.
cons:
Top-down transparency is not where it needs to be. Internal marketing was constant, but decisions that genuinely affected the front line was withheld until the very last minute. Hiring and promotion has been outsourced to a consulting firm, such that one's management, who actually sees your contribution to the organization has no real say in who is promoted and must choose from a predetermined list of applicants. This led to a lack of advancement opportunity for those who deserved it and sub-optimal staffing selection. 
Edit: Bill Pepicello is no longer CEO/President, so take my review of the current CEO with a grain of salt.

review_title: Get what you can and then go
pros: Tuition benefits, flexible scheduling, customer-focused plans and programs
cons: no incentive, career progression is used as a dangling carrot but not determined by people that actually see your work ethic everyday. Always in a state of flavor of the month initiatives - never feels like you can really get used to something before a new plan is rolled out. Very little effort in terms of retaining seasoned employees - sales work without the pay. In addition, they pay for your edu but once you finish there's no progression or salary opportunities for a masters degree.

pros: Training and upgrading faculty skills; commitment to student success; the latest in online technology; excellent faculty and student resources; salary based on years of service, good standing and educational level, and frequent faculty assessment for self-improvement.
cons: Learning platform has frequent changes and courses are revised.  This causes course preparation to be outdated quickly while faculty is scrambling to meet new course requirements; sometimes technological issues are not totally worked out before going "live." It can be difficult to determine who one's immediate supervisor is, there are so many staff members reviewing you. Information is often rapid fire, and it is easy to miss important news or details.

review_title: Constant change provided a valuable learning curve
job_title: Academic Counselor in Baton Rouge, LA
pros: Skills and advancement is encouraged. Self guided work is encouraged and allows individuals personal growth in communication and organizational skills Seeing the student success through advisement given is rewarding. Benefits are competative. The education the students recieve is very applicable to current work situations which prepares the student for future employment readiness.
cons: Realignment of the whole company makes for rocky assurance of future employment. Communication can be slow from the top and even though they promote front line input they do not always ask for it.

review_title: Great benefits and salary, poor management and no room to move up.
job_title: Senior Academic Counselor in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Most of the people are really great to work with and you do bond with your teams.  The benefits are really great as well.  Great opportunities to gain experience if you are fresh out of college.
cons:
There is little to no room for advancement.  Managers and Senior Managers make promises they can't keep.  Also, you seem to have to be "in" with the managers in order to get promoted.  As much as they push for good numbers and customer service, it doesn't matter if you want to get promoted - you have to be BFFs with Senior Managers to even have a chance.  
Also, there is constant change, change of policies, teams, managers, etc.

review_title: This company does not care about employees
pros: It is a paycheck and they have benefits.  No other pros that I can think of at this time.  There is not much good to say. I can't even come up with 20 good words to say about this company.
cons: Pay is not good especially when a degree is required.  The company has unrealistic expectations of employees.  There is no room for personal growth or development.  Managers do not know how to manage people.  To expect new employees to perform at the same level as tenured people is an unfair standard. When you have a new employee that out performs a tenured employee, there is no compensation for the new employee.

review_title: A has been, top heavy sales organization on the decline. Get out now.
pros: Free education tuition waiver, but they'll take it away if you give them any reason at all.
cons: Up the chin in beauracracy. None of the managers from Director down have ANY authority. HR is corrupt, there only to protect the firm. Lot's of well established politics; must stay in your place in the pecking order. Very siloed; one hand has no idea how it's actions affect the other functions of the company. Leadership is weak, more about being a "company guy" than doing what is right. This probably speaks for most of corporate America, but I've never seen such well pronounced beauracracy.

review_title: UOP is like  a call center
pros: Great learning experience.   Learning about the " Corporate" world.  Learn great sales strategies, learn about the education industry, and get your foot in the door.
cons: Everything is about the student , what about the employees? Employees are not treated well.  Its very much a call center enviroment if you work in the online division.  Micromanagement is HIGH.  If you want the freedom to work in a happy healthy enviroment where you like what you do you are better off working for another company.  Employees do not get paid what they are worth, and what hard work they put in.

review_title: The Job is not what it used to be
pros: Good Vacation & Salary with Tenure
cons:
The Job has transited from having a team of students you work closely with & partner with an Academic Counselor to assist, to that of a call center & performance expectations that make you feel like a robot.
Micro Management tactics & the delay of passing on Information & changes in policy has been a problem for a while now as well.  It's become more stressful to work than ever used to be.

review_title: Local campus is great but Apollo corporate policies were inconsistent.
pros: Great people at the local campus. Local leadership is strong and there is a commitment to the employees. Education is strongly valued and the staff is highly educated. Tuition is free for employees. Teamwork is emphasized and it is a very professional environment. Decent pay and good benefits.
cons: Corporate policies often didn't make sense, local campus could not make local decisions. Never know if corporate will decide on layoffs. Messages are always that students come first, but also corporate needs to remember to be open and honest with employees and not treat them like they can be replaced or eliminated at any time. Formerly, people could grow and build long-term career. Now, new policies make it practically impossible to move up in the company. Growing into a leadership position from within is non-existent.

job_title: Senior Enrollment Advisor in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Love my co-workers and helping students reach their goals and dreams. I have been here for about eight years so I was to learn a lot in those years. Not too many people can say they kept the same job for this many years. I was able to get my education paid for so that is a benefit.
cons: Lack of growth. Money could definitely be a lot better. I see them working on it, but it shouldn't have to take years for you to realize you need to pay your employees more. After a while you want to feel that you are appreciated and can move up with in the company. I don't see that and it is not going to happen anytime soon.

job_title: Academic Affairs Coordinator in Raleigh, NC
pros: The company is very innovative and mixes face to face classroom experience with virtual classroom. The students have the opportunity to have hands on experiences.
cons: Unfortunately the campus I was working for will soon close it doors. The company has centralized many of its operations  based on student enrollment thus causing many campus to be closed down.

review_title: I don't say this lightly -- it's freaking fantastic here
job_title: Senior Internal Communications Specialist in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Incredibly supportive atmosphere; great pay; opportunity for advancement; leadership who actually cares about whether you like where you work; responsive and involved leadership team; excellent on-boarding; no surprises and never having to wonder what happens next or what's expected of you; i can NOT express enough how positive and supportive the culture is; holy COW is this place great
cons: I mean, beyond not being able to go to my actual office (they have CINNAMON TOAST CRUNCH. for FREE), I can't think of a single genuine con to this job. I've been here for three months, and I'm still more and more excited about this job every. single. day. I've never felt this way about a job, and it's thrilling.

review_title: Nice co-workers but technically behind the market
pros: University of Phoenix was founded with a great mission of providing a way for nontraditional students (those who need to keep working while earning a degree) to receive a degree in higher education. Employees here are very quality and deadline driven; they take pride in their daily responsibilities.
cons: The company has been too tied to its legacy systems which has prevented it from rapidly adapting to technical innovations that could make the online education much more engaging. Top down management style is not empowering; middle managers are implementers. Hence, lack of innovation at the lower levels.

review_title: Campus culture was excellent! Leadership in Phoenix needs GREAT IMPROVEMENT!
pros: The campus I worked at had an amazing culture.  It was a family atmosphere - we didn't care that we were separated by departments; we all worked together as we truly had the students best interest in mind.
cons: LAYOFFS! I was employed at UOP for over 3 years. I was consistently the top advisor in my field, within the entire company for 2 years. Empty promises were made, repeatedly.  I was laid off in November of 2013 without so much as a thank you.

job_title: Academic Counselor in Santa Teresa, NM
pros: Free education (if you're interested in mostly business), 401 K, vacation, medical & dental.
cons: More like working for a corporation than an institution of higher learning, treated poorly by students that expect you to basically hand them a degree, treated poorly by staff, hostile cliquish work environment (back-stabbing coworkers), kind of an unwritten rule that you're expected to kowtow to enrollment staff (but you're not told this initially) that will do anything to enroll students even if that means stretching the truth. Work hours 8-6, low wages.

review_title: Been here 7 years. Inconsistent - watch your back
pros:
Tuition waiver (with a federal cap) 
If you have a good manager and good director, it can be supportive and enjoyable. Leadership seems hopeful that lending sale will turn things around, but some are concerned this is just lip service.
cons: High stress environment has become toxic in some departments - again, hinges upon the revolving door of leadership. Managers are swapped out for convenience to work around HR. Executive deans and other C-levels have golden chutes awaiting them when the sale finalizes, so they make decisions based on improving their resumes rather than actually considering our futures. Performance evaluations force everyone to be rated as "mediocre." Employees rated as "role model" (highest tier) quickly have targets on their backs due to sudden regime change.

review_title: Univeristy of Phoenix is Challenging but lacks focus of the student
pros: Convenience and they are constantly improving, still the academic counselors are difficult to get in touch with and do not return phone calls.
cons: Financial aid officers are not what you will experience on a traditional campus, they are unknowledgable and duties are equivalent of that of a clerk. It is obvious from the get go they are out to get money, as the founder stated they wanted to be the walmart of education, and it shows. They have no knowledge of additional monies and are not able to help beyond what their little data base says in front of them. I asked what my schedule for financial aid would be and they told me that I "need to understand that there are a lot of students, certification of loans happens when we get around to it." Shocking considering I am a graduate of three other traditional colleges and Universities.

pros: Good benefits, only because of the free education opportunities but with some of the student's being enrolled that benefit won't be as effective anymore!  Work with a majority of good people.  Satisfaction of seeing other people earn there degrees!
cons: Where to start?  Management is so incompetent that it is a wonder the company turns a profit at times.  Enrollment can seem very dim when you have std's who can't even spell Phoenix let alone pronounce disbursement.  The business environment seems more like a day care from time to time.  Call center atmosphere.  Very very unprofessional!!

review_title: Was once a great job, lost some of its luster
pros: Great co-workers, pretty easy to hit numbers and get nice raises, consistent hours, fun activities
cons: Too much regulation and shifting focus on some questionable enrollment practices.  Even when the matrix went away, they still found ways to incorporate numbers and many counselors were frustrated with the inappropriate people who we signed up to go to school - some who would ask us, "how do I open a document in Windows?"  Also, no room for advancement in the most recent years.  UoP will get you stuck.

pros: Good pay, decent hours if you have good numbers and perform well. Decent vacation and sick time.
cons: Ideas for improvement fall on deaf ears, upper management makes no effort to meet lower level employees at their level. Mass emails regarding DAILY changes to enrollment procedures. Literally, every day I'd get a new email stating we were to change our approach improving enrollment...very disheartening because I really cared about my students. Sometimes felt like they wanted us to just do whatever it took to get students to start even if they weren't prepared. I had one manager who I had to complain about nearly ten times, as did the rest of my team. He was finally fired but it took way too long.

review_title: Used to be a great place to work, but has been on a steady decline for years.
pros: The pay isn't bad, the benefits are decent, and they allow breastfeeding mothers a private rooms to pump throughout the day. Tuition waivers for employees, decent amount of vacation time, ability to volunteer off campus  during your shift, and team builders occasionally.
cons: No actual measure of performance therefore everyone gets paid the same despite work ethic. It's impossible to get fired so you work alongside incompetent people and end up having to clean up their messes. Steady decline of benefits and employee appreciation.

pros: Great job if your looking for "free" education. Remember to consider the other areas you are missing out on by receiving free tuition. I would say the salary is competitve and overall it is an ok place to work.
cons: Company has become very bureaucratic and there is limited opportunity in actually climbing the corporate ladder here unless you are in the "in crowd" with upper management. The company ethics really push the boundaries with industry standards which can be hard at times to accept if you have morals. It can be a good move to work for this company however, proceed with caution.

pros: Good salary and some of the best people I ever worked with. Interesting work. Love the fact they are really trying to improve students' lives.
cons: DOWN SIZING and doing it poorly. People are being laid off not because they are not doing a good job or because what they are doing is not in line with the company objectives. Lay offs are necessary with falling enrollment but are frequently political in nature. You can be offered a promotion/incentive one day and laid off the next (literally). High numbers of upper middle managers and deans fleeing.

pros: There is a great sense of camaraderie amongst peers, mostly due to many opportunities to work on cross-functional teams and project.  Because of this, along with the better-than-average education benefit, this is a good place to develop your professional career.
cons: The culture in the organization is one of constant fear and uncertainty. This is mainly due to 5 years + of straight layoffs. Because they continue to struggle to define individual success, you really don't have any control over your own job security, let alone advancement.

review_title: Very fulfilling working with students to reach their goals.
pros: Working with state of the art applications for on-line learning. Helping students to "grasp the knowledge of accounting" and seeing that aha moment.
cons: The time it takes to do "off-line paperwork that is required." There was a large learning-curve to adjust to on-line teaching and not seeing facial expressions and other body-language that can be so telling of the students understanding of concepts and methodology. Many other communication tools have helped overcome this obstacle.  New technology and experience have helped overcome this "con".

job_title: Remote Technical Support Analyst in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Able to help students and faculty overcome technical limitations, thereby improving educational experience.
cons: Management and Quality Departments finding every way possible to ask for the impossible from employees.  Quality is neither valued nor recognized on an ongoing basis.  Poor Queue management and remote worker strategies were too inflexible to be able to offer pleasant experiences, especially for the "slower" customers.

pros: Generous benefit package, friendly co-workers, and a thorough training experience - In my time at U of P I was fortunate to work with some very talented and driven individuals.
cons: Highly metricized work, constant pressure to produce - There were times when the goals we were expected to hit seemed somewhat unattainable. I was hired in a time of transition when metrics were not the focus. That transition stalled a bit, and soon thereafter metrics were again introduced.

job_title: Student Finance Advisor in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Pay is very competitive for positions that require a degree. tuition waiver, paid time off, 401k. Decent medical, dental, vision. Shifts are mostly flexible, but depend on business needs. weekends off, unless you pick up the rare opportunity for overtime.
cons: Absolutely no room for advancement. The company has downsized hundreds of jobs each year that I've been here. They eliminated the entire training department, and are cutting jobs at all levels, so if you have hope for a promotion, don't. Hard work is not rewarded. If you have a good manager, you may get a compliment or a pat on the back, but nothing tangible like bonuses or pay increases.  Your pay is based on how long you've been there, not how well you do your job. You cap out on salary at 5 years.

pros: Working with students and being exposed to coaching them and being their mentor was extremely challenging and rewarding. My manager was very hands off and allowed us to complete our workflow in our own ways, so long as things got done and metrics were hit, very little intervention. I did see opportunities to advance my own skills had I worked there longer than the year roughly I was there.
cons: At the Axia level, I felt there were a lot of students that should not be in school. To be blunt, not everyone should go to school and there has to be better expectations set for students about what is or is not realistic. I know the company has evolved a lot since I last worked there, but they seem to still carry a bad PR.

job_title: Senior Corporate Counsel in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Its obvious when your boss and leadership care about you - and that is something UOPX has; they care about their employees. My pay and benefits are good; my workload is appropriate and never boring; people are respectful and smile at me everyday; and the little things that make coming to work enjoyable are cultivated (like good food options, gym and fitness classes, team building areas, stand-up desks, nice facilities, great training and onboarding). I am not getting lost in the corporate shuffle and my work product is appreciated. There is opportunity for  growth which is fostered and the business outlook is good. I look forward to growing and changing with UOPX into the future.
cons: Traffic (my commute) to/from work can be a little tough, but it's worth it!

review_title: I must have missed something during the interview process describing the job?
pros: Great opportunity to assist the lifelong student with preparations to finally get a college education.  Employees & their dependents can enroll into any Apollo Group higher education school for a free college degree up to graduate level. Great 1st job if you are straight out of college or the military.
cons: UOPX stays under radar for a reason…still numbers driven to sell a education, no change there no matter what marketing tells the media.  The enrollment counselor position will not survive without enrollments, so expect another round of lay-offs soon, period.  Not a career minded place to work unless you enjoy sitting and dialing the same students all day.

review_title: Taking some steps in the right direction with employee compensation
job_title: Senior Enrollment Advisor in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Educational opportunity if you do not have your undergraduate degree.
cons:
Too many changes, appearance of no clear vision from executive leadership. These changes do not appear to be thought out (taking successful projects out of experienced hands to have them flounder and die in inexperienced ones with minimal training). "Ready, Fire, Aim!"
Lack of admissions standards allow many people abusing the financial aid system into the mix.

review_title: Give your best and you'll find happiness!
pros: Excellent benefit package.  Opportunities for advancement if you're flexible, especially willing to relocate.  They truly do provide a great service with integrity, despite the negative press that happens with being the largest.
cons: Pay not as generous as others.  A tendency to practice the "Peter Principal" and at the lower management levels Directors seem to hire for manager positions those persons that would not appear to threaten their own position.  Insecurity and immaturity in lower management positions too common.

review_title: I loved it for the first 5 years I worked there. They forgot about there employees with all the changes. It's just sad.
job_title: Executive Enrollment Advisor in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Great benefits, paid holidays, up to 5 weeks of vacation and 2 weeks of sick time, free tuition.
cons: High pressure, no job security, little room to move up, pay raises are now infrequent, not rewarded for hard work, very negative environment. Leadership was not honest, which was a big part of why I left.

review_title: Great people, good place to work
job_title: Senior Academic Counselor in Phoenix, AZ
pros:
Helping "high risk" college students graduate and reach their goals
Working with great people.  My coworkers probably kept me there a few years longer than I would have stayed without them.
Developing skills to manage all different walks of life.
cons:
A bit too much micromanagement.
Little opportunity for recognition/advancement

job_title: Faculty Advisor/Adjunct Faculty/Clinical Supervisor in West Bloomfield, MI
pros: As faculty you are able to provide meaningful and beneficial information to students learners.     You can impact their knowledge base in a positive manner, professionally, academically and spiritually. Empowerment relative to everyday decision making life skills.
cons: There is a need for more on-ground campus in the community, not fewer on-ground facilities. Enable working class, mature individuals to seek an education that can offer upwards mobility. Younger students can also benefit from the community presence of more on-ground college campuses, as well.

review_title: Excellent continuing education; moderate salary compensation
pros:
Regularly offers free continuing education for excellence in  teaching/ classroom engagement skills
Faculty invited to participate in Best Practice discussions and syllabus review
Curriculum designed to help clarify student competencies achieved each week 
New provision of career services to faculty
cons:
Salary not increased in proportion to amount of time required for preparing and posting student feedback for up to three assignments per week
Recent cessation of stock awards for faculty involvement in activities beyond classroom 
Reduction in remuneration for attending faculty meetings. best practices workshops and graduation

pros: Practitioner faculty have a broad range of "real-world" knowledge and experience. Provides flexibility with physical classroom or on-line modalities. The Online Learning System facilitates the learning process via electronic assignments, virtual organizations, simulations, tutorials, student feedback, and writing guides.  The on-line library provides students and faculty access to a vast number of peer reviewed journals and other electronic resources. Plagiarism tools and  training assist faculty members with enforcing stringent academic integrity policies.
cons: Faculty members reach salary cap after 3 years with a terminal degree.  For-profit status presents challenges under fair-use copyright law.  There are no entrace exams, so some students are not properly prepared for college.

review_title: Good. I've worked at UOP for 5 years. Overall, I'm grateful for my experience.
pros: My team is student focused, we care about the best interest of the student. I always felt that the company treated me fair. Great benefits. I feel good about the work we do.  I've enjoyed working for the University of Phoenix. However, the pay structure and incentives have drastically changed in the last 3 years.
cons: The industry is changing and cut backs have been difficult (ex: layoffs, less money spent on employees). It's not the same place that it used to be. Due to restrictions, they cannot reward hard workers with compensation, there are significantly more online school competition, and less students are enrolling in education all over the country. It's a tough time to work in education.

review_title: It's been a long tough 2 recent years
job_title: Student Services Manager in Phoenix, AZ
pros: The Salary and benefits are good.
cons: Morale is terrible, and they don't really seem to know what to do to help the University to succeed in this new environment.  They throw a lot of things out there and hope they stick, but there isn't a lot of follow through or real commitment to initiatives.

review_title: Maybe a good start for teaching - but you will probably want to move on to better institutions.
pros:
Work from home - or where ever!  Able to keep up with the current advances in your particular field.  
Enjoyed interacting with others.
cons:
Pay is nothing to write home about.  For the hours and the dedication, you must like what you are doing to continue to teach at UoP.  The audits of the classroom suggest that instructors should spend significant amounts of time teaching, reading and grading - more than what they are compensated for.
Many students, even in the Master's Programs should not be there.  There seems to be no screening for admission, other than an ability to pay.

job_title: Senior Financial Counselor in Phoenix, AZ
pros: The team environment was a joy while working there, I'm hopeful they did not do away with the work pods as was being discussed. The three Admissions counselors to one Financial Counselor was the perfect balance..(most of the time).  The rapport and friendships to come of that were memorable and joyful.
cons: Of course, they were consistently changing things that didn't need changing.  One of the changes on the table was to do away with teams altogether and have it be an anonymous dial-er...basically you get whichever AC is available and then transferred to whichever anonymous FC that happens to be available.  It seemed impersonal and lacked that extra touch.  PLEASE - stop changing things that have worked beautifully for years and years

pros:
The direct supervisor of some of the faculty answers emails quickly
The direct supervisor tries to allay fears of faculty in losing their jobs
The university provides many opportunities for professional learning
Class sizes small (about 14), if one has larger classes, they get additional pay.
cons:
The pay is pretty bad for a PhD
The yearly evaluation is not a fair or representative evaluation of the faculty
They are changing the curriculum and without notice can end your employ there
No advancement opportunities
Seems to hire personal friends over qualified faculty
Does not listen to faculty
Fired some of my friends without warning, just decided to dissolve a whole department of full time faculty.

review_title: Loved the University per se but the clique-ish approach to promotion within Spfd MO Campus turned me off.
pros: Campuses are nationwide and growing worldwide.
cons: It is so huge that it becomes very difficult for corporate/company leaders to notice employees (i.e enrollment managers) who really are paramount in bringing about success in terms of new enrollment, retention,and ending enrollment. There were instances in the past that some people got promoted because of who they know as opposed to performance.

review_title: Tons of potential, very poor execution
pros: Huge company with the opportunity to learn from talented leaders.
cons: Executive management has made several poor decisions that they continue to shift the blame onto front-line employees for.  The environment is chaotic, uninspired and reactive.  Directors are useless and were most likely promoted due to being there at the right time.  Managers are forced to deliver bad news to employees on a weekly basis regarding lack of career opportunities, dwindling leads or performance issues yet the company refuses to pay top performers for their hard work.

pros: 5 week courses; great for additional income and great turn around to make more. Hybrid courses - Face to Face  with all assignment submissions online! Curriculum for all courses developed by UoP, Instructor only needs to personalize and set up the online tools available!
cons: Too many instructors hoarding classes. New Instructors fight to get what one can. Administration not timely or effective in returning calls, emails, or answering questions. Administrators ask for you to choose next class to teach so they can schedule & fill with students BUT do not give those classes to new instructors.

pros:
The front-line employees are exceptional.
The location is very easy to commute to from across the valley.
The schedules make an attempt to help avoid the worst Phoenix traffic.
Dr. Slottow is very good to work for.
cons:
Many of the managers, the directors, and senior company leaders are some of the most despicable people it has ever been my displeasure to meet and work for.
Leadership inertia makes all changes surface deep instead of organizational wide and effective.
Mid-Level managers are inward focused and only support what benefits themselves, not the people under them and not the customers/students benefits.

job_title: Campus College Chair, School of Business in San Francisco, CA
pros: Innovative institution pioneering in higher education of working adults. I teach in all three modalities: face-to-face (in-class), online and hybrid. Excellent computerized faculty service system and great online platform.  Unique faculty development system, plenty of methodological assistance and support.
cons: Although the university is champion in offering higher education to working adults from various social groups of the society, in my opinion, it should become now more active in the international arena, expending its unique experience and success in the countries of Eastern Europe, Eurasia, and other continents.

review_title: The University is a great middle position job market. Its not for the enrty level positions, but not for the experienced
pros: The University through the years offers a lot of perks for people with tenure. Great time off, very felxible on working hours and a lot of great people around you to pass the day along nicely.
cons: The University makes advancing changes often and its hard to keep track of why. They often seem to make decisions without thinking them through on how to relay them down to impliment them. Change is good, but if its too often it wears down the employees.

pros: The company has more opportunities for advancement. You are evaluated fairly with the companies standard matrix. Raises can be up to 20% every 6 months. If an employee advance to executive enrollment counselor, then their making nearly 100k. Very laid back environment.
cons: So many changes that effect the number of students you can enroll and the company does not make the appropriate adjusts. The company recently rolled out a new initiative which makes it harder to enroll and retain students, however, employees are still expected to make the same quota. The companies sometimes bends the truth to students.

pros: Employees are given incentive's to do well with promotions and raises.  There is also a lot of coaching, training, and development opportunities.  If you do well you can make good money.
cons: Selling education is difficult.  You can be put in uncomfortable situations to sign a student up. If you do not believe in the education or the way they promote it working for t he company can be very difficult.  There is a lot of pressure to perform as well, it is very competitive in nature.

pros:
It's a job

Great Benefits

Good starting/entry salary
cons:
This is absolutely the WORST company I have ever worked for!!! Backstabbing, gossip, lying-and that's from management!! 

Micromanaging to the 100th power: you not only clock in and out, you have to clock out (AUX) each and every single time you step away from your desk. If you go to the bathroom, to the break room, to the copy room, or even to ask a question to a coworker in another cubicle you better be sure to AUX in and out or you're in trouble.

They could care less about students - it's all about enrollments. They claim it's not a sales job because of government regulations, but trust that Enrollment is nothing but hardcore sales and cold calls.

review_title: Working in student services at UOPX
pros: Competitive pay for what the job entails. Overtime occasionally offered but we were not expected to work it if we didn't want to. Work life balance is important and it was stressed that we do not work more than 40 hours a week. Typically, job expectation were known.  Job is easy to learn.
cons: No room for growth. Pay increases not based on merit. Too much micromanaging. The company decides when each individual can take a lunch or break.

review_title: good for employees, bad for students
pros: lots of vacation time, decent starting pay, majority of coworkers are nice
cons: It's difficult watching people accumulate so much debt for a degree only to immediately go into another program upon graduating at the encouragement of his or her enrollment advisor. Instead of suggesting people start another program in order to defer their loans/feel good about themselves, UOP should partner with more places for students to do internships and network so they can later get jobs.

review_title: Everyone seems to be growing except us!
pros: Great people, opportunity to jump onto new projects, good work-life balance.
cons: The University is constantly cutting staff and budget.  The layoffs and constant org changes have really soured morale and created a survival of the fittest environment.  Its very frustrating to see every other company in the Phoenix area growning while we are barely making ends meet.

pros: Work week Monday thru Friday, good people to work with, vacation time, pay is decent, and reviews every six months.
cons: Management favors- doesn't praise/promote people that deserve it.  Pretty much a call center, UOP is open enrollment- some students are there for the financial aid- not education.  Some campus' target homeless shelters to recruit potential students.  Constantly watched in every way possible!  Never fully staffed- high turnover. Many counselors never feel good enough, most are disappointed with reviews and raises.

review_title: Overall, it was a great experience, I learned a lot there.
pros: The team is great to work with, helping people to further their education was very rewarding.  Great leadership for the most part.  Work life balance was pretty good as well.
cons: The pay and no sense of job security.

pros: There are great educational benefits, you work in an industry that helps to make positive change in students' lives, there's a great culture.
cons: Health benefits are OK (pretty expensive but comparable in price and overall benefit to most other employers).  The industry is shrinking and political pressure on "for profit" private universities has made job stability here difficult - many reductions in force with no end in sight.

pros: Free tuition, many great people to work with, cafe onsite, fairly generous paid time off.
cons: Difficult to move into new areas internally, chronic change and flurry of similar looking initiatives. Restricted growth in terms of advancing, due to restructuring many positions are not replaced once vacated.

pros:
I felt welcomed and valued right away.  The environment is fairly casual and friendly.  You can personalize your workspace including requesting eronomic adjustments which is definitely needed.  

Change happens quite fast so if you like to always know what you are going to be doing or where you will be working - this might not be the best place for you.
cons:
The facilities are "odd" and a bit dreary - the work areas are all gray, the walls are gray, there is no artwork, there is poor lighting which creates eye strain and fatigue.  

Sometimes change happens so fast it's hard to keep up and it can also be difficult to maintain productivity.

job_title: Enrollment Advisor in Lone Tree, CO
pros: Great people to work with. Love working with the students. The University truly does have a great product to offer a demographic that may otherwise not be able to continue their education
cons: They have hired people and then laid a bunch of people off shortly after. No communication between the campuses and the team making the organizational changes. Turning enrollment into a call center and local enrollment advisers can no longer enroll ground on their campus (true for majority of campuses, but not all). They have no possible career progression in place and they lie about how they are unable to provide more than a cost of living raise annually which does not cover the total cost increase of insurance and taxes.

review_title: People, Enough! Nobody Is Staying Here Or Leaving Eventually!
pros: Here is one pro...the buildings are air conditioned.  If you work in Arizona you will need a working AC unit.
cons: There is no personal growth or opportunity at UOP at this point.  New hires will not be able to achieve the high salary of those who were there in the glory days.  You will be expected to enroll the same amount of students, just for less than half the pay.  When you leave, the only skill you will be able to show a future employer is that you can "sell", because that is what you are doing.  This is a sales job, period, nothing about this is education.  The majority of students will bail after they receive their first Pell check.

pros: The pay was decent because I received 2 increases but it was initially  non-negotiable.
cons: When you start  working it's not what you assume. I was thinking that I would be meeting students but instead I was made to sit on the phone. Then there were tons of layoffs, members of upper management abandoning ship. There is too much favoritism and clicks. Even in terms of leadership and how they click up with other advisors. Don't waste your time.  This job is a waste and it's only a matter of time.  The company was recently sold so hopefully they will improve but still run and don't look back

pros: The job itself is not bad, I enjoy helping students find programs that will help, and love their gratitude at graduation!  Tuition benefits an obvious perk as well.
cons: Constant layoffs, management that encourages you to constantly live in fear of losing your job.  No pay increases, opportunity for advancement has all been taken away.  Make the same amount after 3 years as a brand-new hire makes right off the bat.  Some management that does not know how to manage to people and are stuck in the "old ways" of only managing to numbers instead of managing to create the best student experience.

job_title: Senior Financial Aid Officer in Phoenix, AZ
pros: The tuition benefit and the corporate gym are the only pros that I can think of here at the University of Phoenix.
cons: There aren't many opportunities to move up with all of the recent layoffs.  The pay has been reduced to market increases only.  Unfortunately, those are wiped out and you end up paying out more each paycheck towards the raising insurance benefits which are less than mediocre. There are zero incentives for working smart/hard.

review_title: Lots of work but even more instability
job_title: Student Support Coordinator in Phoenix, AZ
pros: free/significantly reduced higher education for workers after 1 year of service.
cons: The company had unstable management, frequent layoffs, frequent team changes, high pressure sales and quotas to be met and the position was mostly taking angry calls from students who were not set up for success. Additionally, the job was described as a counselor type position. It was no more than a glorified call rep. Very disappointing when I took it thinking I would be working to help people.

pros: Free classes for employees, and you are encouraged to take them.  Very good health benefits.  Clean work environment, intelligent people to work with.  If you care more about profit than people, you can make a lot of money.
cons: Ruthless.  Very hard core sales environment. Think Glen Gary Glen Ross.  I have been in sales for 30 years and never had such high  pressure to sell.  If you really care about students and want what is best for them you will have a hard time being successful.  Although they attempt to hide it behind their "matrix" to stay under the legal radar, your pay depends on how many students you can enroll.

pros:
Great adjunct teaching position starting out
Students are great
Variety of course offerings and programs
Several campuses in the DMV area
cons:
Poor pay compared to other for profit institutions
Support varies for faculty dealing with student issues
Can be stuck teaching the same courses and it can be repetitive and boring
Some department heads are rude, incompetent, insensitive and are not supportive of faculty growing
Some department heads apply favoritism when assigning courses

job_title: Adjunct Online Instructor in Greenville, SC
pros: Teaching online allowed me to work from home. The students were friendly and open to learning. My colleagues were courteous and helpful.
cons: I understand some courses may require less work than others, but the English (basic, essay writing, etc.) courses required an incredible amount of grading time. The rubrics provided by the school made grading tedious, complex and time-consuming. In general, the school's strict practices about the management of online courses and submission of grades were too much work for the money. I had as many as 44 students at a time and never averaged more than $1K per month. They also require a long, unpaid training program. Nice people, but there are better adjunct jobs.

pros: The benefits are pretty great. You do get a free education up until your masters of course. However, I'm not sure if that is still a go there. Fast paced in the financial department and awesome people to work with. There are a lot of company parties especially for the holidays. Awesome team builders (depending on the manager and funds). Very diverse in the company.
cons: In order to excel you do have to know someone... that's the saying for most companies now. Depending on your manager, it can be a pain sometimes. Finance department has it harder than anyone else. No one likes to talk about money... Work/life balance.... I've seen better at major construction companies.

job_title: Customer Service Specialist in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Undergraduate Education paid for (degree required).  Benefits.  13 year employee;  The early days for University of Phoenix were exciting and positive; later years disappointing.
cons: Too many  changes required to remain competitive and response to investigations; new computer systems; reorganizations; not enough consistency within management to achieve required goals. As of late incredibly high-stress environment.

review_title: Big company lacking compassion or loyalty
pros: As a large employer the training program and company resources are quite good. Most jobs are assigned to a large number of employees who you can ask for insight & support to get you up to speed. Large company benefits include healthcare & corporate discounts.
cons: Sadly, repeated waves of layoffs mean job security is a constant worry. The leadership is determined to ignore feedback from frontline employees and continuously fails to address persistent communication & compensation issues.

review_title: Good company to work for, if looking for contract based work
pros: Can work at home, work on own pace and schedule. Job becomes easy once you know what to do.
cons: Pay is only given AFTER the end of the class you are assigned to, typically 6-8(!) weeks later, plus time for mailing the check to you. Taxes are NOT paid for either. Be careful if you are not used to this kind of work, it can be very financially draining...

pros: This is a large organization, part of the Apollo Education Group. Benefits are great!
cons: Lots of change in direction leaving many employees out of work over the past 6 months. The University needs strong leadership to navigate these changes and would do well to think about cutting bonuses and spending at upper levels during this time of change. The metrics have become more important than the goals.

review_title: Too many changes. Everyone was uneasy and lacked job security
pros: Free tuition for school, great health insurance and benefits, many perks as an employee. All of these things went from the best I had ever experienced to just "ok". Not sure how they are now. Great training and one on one coaching
cons: Their HR processes stink, very heavy on sales in enrollment, a lot of "good ole boys" clubs, people getting promoted for no good reason, if you aren't in their club you will not move up, changes they make can be detrimental to your job and no one cares. The company turns a blind eye to illegal use of financial aid.

review_title: great mid and low level but horrible VPs
pros: Amazing mid level management a lot of great leaders that should be in higher positions,. Amazing CEO he is very hands on and extremely involved.
cons: VP level management are not  strong leaders a select few got there by luck and don't know how to manage large projects or leader the employees under them. Oe in particular was very upfront and honest about how he got to where he was by simply brown nosing  and that he knew nothig but how to be in the right place at hte right time.

pros: Great people, very diverse environment. Great education benefits for employees and their family.
cons: No opportunity to grow. Whichever position you started with, that is where you are staying. They might move you several times from team to team, or change your manager every couple of months....They keep changing the guidelines regarding the way you are suppose to do your work. Management is dishonest and constantly uses fear tactics with their employees.

pros: I worked here almost three years and I loved working with my students. The salary was good. My co-workers were great!
cons: Upper management is terrible, middle management is worst because they share nothing with you and because of upper management blaming sales for not being able to turn horrible leads into registered students and management would micromanage to try and get enrollment to squeeze water out of a rock. In addition there are constant layoffs. New, old, performing, you're always at risk. Some managers use reviews to ensure who will be laid off. No growth. Mormon preference. Upper management is mostly white men.

job_title: Senior Enrollment Advisor in Phoenix, AZ
pros: My Director, Jessica Jay-Maleski, was one of the most impressive leaders I have ever worked with. She is young, but she is driven and focused beyond belief. Her work ethic was far superior to that of the other directors in the division and it showed - our team was always on top! I appreciate all she did for me during my time on her team.
cons: Due to lack of opportunity at the higher levels of leadership, Jessica Jay-Maleski and many others had to look elsewhere for promotion opportunities.

pros: Flexible hours, well organized administration, efficient IT systems
cons: Healthcare law limited the number of classes you can teach part time without requiring insurance coverage.  I have a full time job with full benefits with another company and enjoyed teaching more classes at UOP, but the government limited my classes and earning potential trying to fix the healthcare law which has nothing to do with my teaching and yet, here we are.   Not UOP's fault just my only con.  I love working at this place.

job_title: Senior Enrollment Advisor in Chicago, IL
pros: Great training, good entry level sales techniques, breaks down barriers to continue your career in other fields, awesome tuition reimbursement plan, good people, good product. I worked with very ethical advisors who tried their best to always do right by their students and the school.
cons: This is not for the weak of heart. This is a sales job, not college admissions. If you don't think that you can be on the phone for 8 hours a day and make outbound calls to strangers, this probably isn't for you.

review_title: Some good benefits if you can tough it out
pros: Great benefits including choosing a variety of schedules, Flex time is available, free tuition for any degree the school offers, 401k match, and a generous amount of vacation time for those who have been with the company
cons: Depending on the role, some positions on the phone are subject to micromanaging.  It can be difficult to move around in the company as many positions are very departmentalized.

job_title: QC Administrative Clerk in Phoenix, AZ
pros: I was with this company for 11 years and worked for 5 different departments over the years. Overall I had a nice experience working there. Toward the end though, it wasn't that good. Mostly due to changes in the department I worked in and management. I would still overall recommend it as a good place to work.
cons: Cons? I would say for me personally location. It was a way to drive. The moved operations to Phoenix and it was in Tempe for many years.

review_title: A good place to teach as an adjunct faculty
pros: University of Phoenix is a good place to teach as an adjunct faculty to get some additional income. They hire people who are in the professional field to teach the subject they really know. They provide a good support and a fair compensation.
cons: It is not quite clear how their rotations on the workload works. Sometimes you get classes and sometimes you don't. I guess, a lot depends on the  faculty scheduler.

review_title: Contact Specialist (Outbound Contact Center Rep Outbound)
job_title: Outbound Contact Specialist in Phoenix, AZ
pros:
Sick/Vacation Time
Ability to work Holidays if you want (Either schedule it off and get holiday pay or work to make time & a half)
Flexible hours 5am-2pm through 12pm-9pm
Tuition benefits after 6 months
cons: Little to no opportunity to move up within department.  You can move up to be a supervisor if it becomes available. You have to wait at least one year to change departments.

job_title: Enrollment in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: I really enjoyed aspects of University of Phoenix.  My team was great, the salary and benefits were good, and I earned a masters degree free of charge.  I also feel like I learned a lot of valuable skills that translate well to other jobs.
cons: The University is in a state of flux right now in the midst of increased regulation, competition, and media scrutiny of proprietary institutions.  As a result the company continues to introduce different initiatives- many of which haven't worked.  Also, the university has had frequent layoffs for nearly four years.

job_title: Enrollment Representative in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Health and life insurance. Education benefits as long as work expectations were met.
cons: Call center environment. Lots of pressure to meets required performance. Performance measured in an overwhelming number of activities. Some expectations are conflicting creating stress. Management has become negative, condescending, and belittling in a effort to motivate. Increasing micromanagement of employees and low trust level.

pros:
I've been with this company for over a decade and the culture has really changed, very much for the better. So here's some of the pros from the past five years. 

 - No crunch time. 
- Leadership is very understanding of personal issues, especially during pandemic. 
 - There are definite career progression paths and training opportunities to help you grow, even if you grow out of Univ. of Phoenix
A positive, but realistic attitude among my vertical. 
Minimal knowledge silos, and those are being worked to remove every day. There's lots of encouraging of knowledge transfers.
cons: I honestly don't have any complaints.

review_title: Education Business Development for University of Phoenix
job_title: Corporate Education Liaison in Tukwila, WA
pros:
Excellent support infrastructure and well trained sales team make hitting performance goals realistic.  Reasonably compensation package, with excellent potential for growth.
Education is free while employed with the University.
cons: High turn-over in some support roles make create headaches while replacements are trained and brought up to speed.  In some markets there is a negative perception of the University. National marketing campaigns do little to improve perception by primary business clients.

review_title: Excellent course design, great faculty forums, great to be working for a place where students actually learn!
pros: Students are actually learning at Phoenix. The program of instruction is not dumbed down, a phenomenon which is typical all over the country in face-to-face colleges of all kinds. Students at the University of Phoenix are acquiring the basic skills that students should learn in high school but never do. In addition they are learning communicative skills, and a respectful attitude between students and students and teachers is promoted - not only encouraged. I think the program is great academically, and therefore it is is a pleasure to work for them. Administrators tend to be polite. You can work from home and work whenever you want - classes are not in real time.
cons: It's hard to know people, and no recommendations are provided. It is not possible to get praised for one's work. The School of Advanced Studies is not rigorous enough, nor is it personable enough so that you could eventually make friends. It is highly bureaucratic, to the point of being stultifying - I am referring to SAS requirements, documents, etc. Too many inexperienced people apply to the dissertation program.

pros: Reasonable pay but unreasonable time expectations for additional training requirements
cons: Dealing with unqualified students who expect an "A" for poor quality work. Paid tuition is considered the primary requirement for an "A" grade. Poor initial counseling and enrolling poor qualified students results in good students changing schools. Unreasonable five week courses are for "gifted" students not welfare to work losers taking federal financial aid to only create classroom problems and then drop out.

job_title: Senior Enrollment Advisor in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Trying hard to think of any pros...except that we all felt like we were in it together...Perhaps the fact that I was able to earn a lot of money - it did compensate because I was a long time employee.  I worked my butt off to earn it though.
cons: Constantly changing - on a dime.  Never completing one initiative before going on to the next - employees don't take anything seriously anymore.  Everyone just laughs at every initiative and calls it the "flavor of the month"  The goals were almost totally unattainable - the stress was overwhelming.  People are so stressed and afraid to even take vacation.  People work when they are sick.  Tragic atmosphere.

job_title: Technical Support Analyst in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Some nice people work here as with any place. Those in the lower to mid level positions seem to care about students and coworkers and want to see them succeed.
cons: Management is completely detached from the day to day. Communication is terrible and it gives the feeling that one hand does not know what the other is doing. Upper management doesn't seem to be held accountable for major failures.

pros: Fun, casual dress code, the people are cool and everyone was pretty helpful/supportive
cons: never know when youre next...tons of layoffs all the time...they don't value their employees

job_title: Senior Finance Advisor in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Excellent benefits, tons of vacation time, free to almost free education, set schedule and you don't have to work weekends, amazing people.
cons: It's a sinking ship. Morale is at an all time low. I was there for almost 7 years and it started out wonderfully and unfortunately due to new regulations for for profit schools, it made things get more difficult. No room for advancement at all any more. No raises and with everyone leaving, it's double or triple the work and having to listen to ungrateful students screaming at you for things out of your control. I do hope it gets better for them one day.

job_title: Senior Interaction Specialist in Phoenix, AZ
pros:
1. Employee friendly environment
2. Great people to work with
3. Easy access to leadership and management to raise your concerns.
4. Open communication from leadership to all employee and clarity on organizational growth.
5. Friendly atmosphere and great campus to spend your break time and relax before getting back to work.
cons: I haven't come across any cons as of now.

review_title: Ok sometimes....just depends on your manager.
pros:
Good benefits
Friendly co-workers
Great vacation/sick time allotted
Ethical in almost all cases
Supportive in most cases
Degree has quality
cons:
Starting pay/salary as an Advisory
Confusion in company direction
Not a growing industry
Regulated industry with bad reputation
Confusion on performance- 
Manager has a lot of say in how you are reviewed and seen

review_title: Pay is not worth it, internal Faculty reviews are a joke for a non-accredited institution.
job_title: Adjunct Faculty (Online) in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Work is remote and can be done anywhere.
cons: LOW Pay. Approx $1100 per 5-week class is the standard with ONE class per 2 months. But they pay SUZE ORMAN much more for the one class she teaches. Faculty review includes a "practitioner's knowledge review" that is subjective according to your assigned reviewers limited knowledge. Yet the University will reprimand you for low student retention if one grades papers at University-level standards. UOP is not a regionally accredited institution.

job_title: Precertification Specialist, FIN Aid Officer, Disburement Off in Phoenix, AZ
pros: There are many good benefits such as tuition waiver to go to school as well as health benefits and support to make healthy choices
cons: Although there are opportunities for advancement, it can be both difficult and competitive to get apposition that pays more and in the financial Aid department, there are no performance based pay raises. The only way to get a pay raise is to get another position in the company that pays more or a promotion that is competitive.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Litchfield Park, AZ
pros: The major pros were obtaining a Free education and compensation. Compensation was good due to tenure started at 33k and ended at  53K after working there for 5 years.
cons: Micromanagement, absolutely no work-life balance. Great managers are limited. f you are honest and provide your feedback to upper management, make sure it's something they want to hear otherwise  you will be under their radar.

pros:
- initially started as an advisor with a VERY attractive compensation structure 
- very supportive leadership team
- strong focus on employee development 
- decent recognition program
cons:
- sometimes hard to get upper management to think outside of the box
- not a lot of diversity in upper management 
- high performance equates to autonomy which wasn't always a good thing

review_title: I thought slave labor was outlawed
pros: They sell the place well up front.  The benefits are pretty good if  you don't already have a degree.
cons: Upper manager is ignorant of what really goes on happy they people below them feed them the lines they want to hear.  Local management speaks out of both sides of their mouth - don't work over 40 hours but also be available 24-7.  Make exceptions to every policy they have.  Good ol' boy/girls club.  When they say they change lives, it is framed in the positive but I would take it with a serious grain of salt.

pros: great co-workers who were very talented and could bring a lot to the company
cons: Talent wasted - talent of employees were not used and it was a popularity contest on who moved up. People were not promoted because they were the best fit for the position. Had to call old leads - some 2 years or older where students could have selected another school to complete their degrees but we had to call until they told us to stop calling.

review_title: University of Phoenix in constant transition
job_title: Senior Director Marketing in San Francisco, CA
pros: The team here in San Francisco was great - sadly they are closing this location and laying off the teams. Only a handful of employees are moving to Phoenix or Seattle.
cons:
The university and the parent, Apollo Education Group, are in a constant state of transition. Enrollments are down significantly and the organization continues to try to reinvent themselves to stave off further declines. And save money. 

The decision to close the entire SF office location was to save money, but in doing so, they have bitten off more than the organization can handle.

pros: The company truly wants to do the right thing for their students and customers. We have new leadership, that I am hopeful for.
cons: The organization seems to belive in a socialist form of compensation. The organization only gives a slight annual increase yearly that is less than inflation and the cost of living.  They also fail to recognize individual contributions in the way of compensation. So I can contribute X to the bottom line and my coworker contributes half that, but we get the same raise.

pros: UOP is a great place to begin your career. If you have not held other positions, especially those of responsibility, before than UOP will be a fun work environment while you develop your skills and grow up. Also, you get paid time and a half if you are meeting or exceeding your goals! I made the mistake of working there in an associate role, although I was more qualified for middle and upper management. I got extremely bored with the work I was doing. That is why I say that if you are just beginning and this is your first job, you will love it. You really cannot mess it up unless you are extremely irresponsible. But when the time comes for growth, that is when you may begin to get bored and tired and that threshold is different for everyone. It is an open air environment, and my boss sat right behind me on the floor. You are given training and the people who whine the loudest are given the most assistance. Most people enjoy working there because it is easy and your pay increases every six months unless you are not reaching your goals.
cons:
Not good for people who are at their prime in their career. Everyone begins at the same salary level and from there it is mostly a popularity contest to get to more responsibility. In Phoenix with the low number of college grads and english speaking population, you pretty much have to take what you can get in the way of work, and be happy with it. There, UoP was seen as one of the top places to work. My manager was one of the best, but they micro-manage you on dials (how many times/day you dial the phone) even when you are meeting your goals. Some of the performance review mechanisms are just out of date. If you want a place where you can be autonomous in your role and think for yourself, this is not the place. It is like the McD's of education. 
Since you are working every current month for the next month, management really discourages taking time off. Even though you are given sick days, you face negative feedback and attitudes by your manager when you take them.

review_title: It is a decent job as long as you are buddy-buddy with management
pros: The schedule was relatively flexible and the benefits were well above those of other companies.  there is a cafeteria and gym at the main Phoenix campus.  Covered parking if your shift started early.  Easy to make friends with coworkers.
cons:
The cafeteria is expensive and the gym is packed all the time.  When you leave the company, you don't exist, even to good friends you made there.  
     Management is a bit aloof as to what is really happening with their teams.  Upper management is worse. They both focus too much on the number of students enrolled and not the quality of the students enrolled.  Top performers have low retention but that doesn't matter because their students struggled through the first class and barely managed to pass.  Two weeks into the next class, there is no more responsibility on the part of the enrollment counselor, even when the student drops out during the third week of the class.  
     There is little to no communication when it comes to new programs...they just appear on the website and counselors look like idiots because they don't know about it.  
     My manager was always giving me extra assignments that took away from my smiling and dialing and I ultimately got let go because my numbers were sub-par.  When my manager asked me why my numbers were low, I told him it was because of all the extra crap he makes me do.  If I said no to a project, he would give the dead leads to work with.  If I did the projects, I got better leads but had no time to work them.

review_title: Professional opportunity to teach, coach, be creative and be part of a large, successful organization of higher learning
pros: Make a difference in students' lives; interact with diverse group of faculty and students; ability to teach and manage online classes with flexibility and ability to continue learning and developing skills and knowledge base.  Dynamic discussions!  Challenging and rewarding!
cons: Online positions are part-time adjunct, no commitment or benefits.

pros: They offer FREE education to all employees once the probationary period is over.
cons: They work you like a slave and have zero regard for your personal life or family. They will attempt to guilt you into doing things that are unethical and when it doesn't work they will fire you and say that you are not performing. They will make you work overtime to achieve your monthly SALES goals and will not pay you for the time.

review_title: University of Phoenix is a bitter sweet pill, but more bitter than sweet.
pros:
1) 100% Tuition Reimbursement
2) Above average entry level pay
3) Good training within the field of education
cons:
1) Lack of regard for a balance of personal and work life
2) Micromanaging
3) Periodic demeaning or disrespectful management treatment of employees
4) Extremely high employee turnover

review_title: Great in-between job for 2 years, 1st half with excellent management, 2nd half with greedy management.
pros: FUN environment and fun people to work with! Rewarding job as you feel you are helping people better their lives (especially if you have a nurturing personality, you counsel a lot of students), NOT a sales kind of "phone job", lots of professional training and workshops available to employees, awesome benefits and pay, opportunity for large pay raises every 6 months (1/2 of this is based on hard work, 1/2 on things beyond your control), don't have to bring the job home with you! Free college tuition!!
cons: Luck of the draw with management--I had 9 fellow employees quit due to my manager's harshness and emotional swings, and they still kept her in. Really hard to move up into higher positions, will need to be with the company for years--except for the one or two times a year they try to keep us on all our toes by promoting a employee with 6 weeks experience up to management...then watch her team fall apart, half quit due to her lack of being able to direct them, and they still keep her in!  Had a lot of VERY capable fellow employees interview for management positions for 3+ years before getting them. They do not choose management based on experience or education in the field--thus a lot of managers that are figuring out how to do their job as they go.  This was in Phoenix though, where there were 6+ applicants each time a position opened up.  If you can get a ground campus job, it's MUCH better odds of moving up quickly.

pros: University of Phoenix offers a great product for working adults.  The value proposition is truly life changing for people who do not have the flexibility to go to a full time bachelor or graduate program.  Offer terrific support for students, great tuition benefits to employees, and work/life balance is good.
cons: Many people in senior leadership have not worked anywhere else, as a result, the ideas for growth are stagnant and lack proper execution.

pros: Excellent opportunities to work on a variety of creative projects including developing instructional content for University courses, workshops for both students and faculty, multimedia such as videos, podcasts and interactive online training; and also marketing content for the student facing UOP website.
cons: Depends on which department or college you work in. Some departments are run efficiently while others are mismanaged and lack strong committed leadership. Some departments have strong, collaborative teams while others are more siloed. Smaller teams often do not have enough people to handle the workload and are not always able to produce high quality work. Quality work is sometimes sacrificed to produce greater quantity. Quality work is important to me so I wasn't willing to compromise on that, especially when you are producing higher education courses and training for faculty. The majority of the courses and trainings are at least 80-90 percent good quality, but from a instructional content development and management perspective, there should be more consistency across the University. The reason there isn't more consistency is due to each college and department wanting to direct their own instructional content development. I prefer working with more collaborative teams rather than siloed teams that create inner conflicts with other teams. The working environment is sometimes fast-paced, but inspirational being around educators and students. The main challenge I observed while working there is higher level executives and University decision makers were not often in sync nor understanding the realities of content production. They were constantly striving to keep up with the latest higher education marketing trends rather than trusting the instructional design and development teams to deliver course material that is developed according to sound teaching and learning principles. Also upper management had a tendency to change their minds too often, creating chaos and confusion for people working in content production. When there are deadlines that must be met, allow for enough planning and discussion time before sending directives to content production teams.

pros: Supporting students to reach their goals, feels great. Almost-free tuition through UOP, WIU, and other subsidiaries. Decent benefits package and vacation time.
cons: Upper management seems to make decisions based on business and numbers, and fail to think of how to incorporate it at the student-level...oftentimes putting additional pressures on the counselors and advisors. Managers don't manage anymore, they "coach"...barely.

job_title: Senior Enrollment Advisor in Cleveland, OH
pros: Valuable coaching, training, and experience. Team environment was a plus and the people that worked there on the ground floor were generally great individuals.
cons:
Management was questionable. Some were promoted because they could do their position well and others based on Corporate Politics. That doesn't always translate into the best managers. 

Other then management; there were constant changes that made it difficult for employees to have continuity in their role. You will have to always be open to implementing new rules and procedures in regards to students and processes. Its the nature of the best.

job_title: Assistant Dean + Faculty in Phoenix, AZ
pros:
The institution has made many positive changes, both for students and staff, in recent years.
There is now a lot of opportunity to help drive change as there is no longer a reluctance to new ideas.
I feel supported and encouraged to regularly do my best.
cons: In the past there had been resistance to new ideas, but I no longer see that.

pros: nothing good from this experience. No work life balance at all, the company has no moral values. They treat students and employees like they are the bottom line.
cons: Many of the students they choose to solicit have no business in  college. They will eventually exhaust their loan aggregate limit before they can even they can complete the program then will eventually have to quit school because they are not financially clear to proceed.
