The students will the owe the university a balance along with the students loans and have NO degree and no means to one. which could have been alleviated had the most expensive school on the planet chose be upfront and honest to the students.

pros:
Good pay for what you do
3 weeks of paid training
Good benefits/ sick days vacation days/ team builders
cons:
Shifts. If you are a new hire, you are guaranteed to work 12-9pm for your first year
Mormons everywhere. 0% diversity on the management level. 
Hit or miss when it comes to management. I have had some amazing bosses, and some who aren't qualified to make their own breakfast in the morning. 
Enrolling people in class who can't turn on a computer without calling tech support. 
0 opportunity of career advancement

pros: Great training and camaraderie with fellow workers
cons: Working here started to resemble the "flavor of the month" concerning the approach with students, company philosophy and employee expectations being continuously shifted. If you are okay with having your phone calls monitored and used as a tool for critical debate, then you will be fine here. This is a for profit school, but due to regulations, they were not able to appear like this was a focus. So they came up with different ways of trying to focus on profit without actually saying that was the goal, which was confusing.

pros: Help others improve their lives, decent pay scale, a lot of great co-workers who enjoy helping each other. It was a great place to work when they had a matrix when I first started working their six years ago. Decent tuition benefits.
cons: Many changes over the past six years. Many for the worse. Lay offs. Losing money. Publicly traded so it seems they do more to try and make holders happy over employees.

job_title: Military Enrollment Advisor in Phoenix, AZ
pros: My Enrollment Manager was the best manager I ever had. He had stated that "feedback was a gift" as it will make you better at your position. He was encouraging and pulled no punches if I was not up to snuff. It was a great experience overall and did very well during my time.
cons: Upper management needs to be replaced, PERIOD. They have no idea about what needs to happen in order to be successful.

review_title: Do Not Recommend Anyone to Work in an Advisor Role (Finance, Academics, Enrollment)
job_title: Senior Finance Advisor in Phoenix, AZ
pros:
Hands down University of Phoenix has the best benefits in my opinion. I worked for the company for over 9 years and to have 5 weeks of vacation plus sick time on top of that cannot be beat. In addition, I love the selection of healthcare benefits provided. There is coverage for every budget and plans for all lifestyles. 
My position was essentially M-F so it was great to not have to work on weekends. Overtime was offered occasionally but in my experience it wasn't mandatory, although you may have a manager that "pushes" you to come in.  The benefits is what kept me going most days.
cons:
Management is HORRIBLE. The managers hired were once regular advisors who had great numbers (high retention with student's, low AR balances etc) -- these "Managers" are not at all qualified to be in management positions. Just because you preform well in an advisor role, does not mean you will be a good manager. There is no more professional development - there used to be years and years ago but that is not the case anymore.
You as an advisor (finance, academics, enrollment) are treated not as a person but a body to simply answer the phone, take abusive phone calls from student's, have managers/directors threaten your job. The President of the University changes constantly - which means new objectives. This happens over and over.  The University can never seem to agree on on an initiative and have it stick. Lastly, it was very hard to deal with the caliber of student's that call in everyday. I am generalizing - not all student's were mean, aggressive, verbally abusive, and short tempered...but the majority that you will speak to are. I had calls where I had to excuse myself and cry because the words were so hurtful. That is hard to listen to for 9 years in my case. 
I am not a jilted employee - I preformed well, I volunteered to help other counselors with their work to catch up, I was a lead for my team...I stayed under the radar but you better believe my last day there was the best day of my life. Since then I have slept better, been a happier person, and not been as moody.  I will be grateful for the benefits and the ability to earn my Master's degree for free - but there isn't much else I can say for this place.

pros: --Online teaching is a great way to help others and the time commitment is flexible to an extent.  It is a great way to make some extra income and get a great sense of reward from helping others.
cons: -Opportunities for advancement do not seem to be available and too often the only positions posted are IT or for entry level recruiters.

pros: Supportive management, advancement opportunities, great hours, superb benefits and the work is not difficult. This company rewards hard work and recognizes talent.
cons: The bulk of the job requires lots of tie on the phone. Expect to make a lot of phone calls and be patient with voice mails as you will leave a LOT of messages. Corporate work means you are not family and the company does not care about your personal life.

pros: Coworkers are great and have become my second family. Working for the company has its ups and downs, especially depending on the manager you have. Some are micro-mangers and others are way too laid back. I have enjoyed working at UOP but there is no where to advance to.
cons: Managers styles are like night and day and are never consistent on anything. The workload gets so overwhelming and no one seems to care how stressful it is.

pros: I loved my full-time online coworkers and I had one excellent manager (out of three).  I found my coworkers to be educated, dedicated, and generous above and beyond other universities where I've worked.  Unfortunately, all 220 of them were laid off suddenly in Feb. 2017.
cons: 15+ levels of management where the highest levels are given huge bonuses although all teachers are told there is no money for COL or merit increases.  Massive turnover in staff; constant and cringeworthy changes to procedures and software; poor morale; ridiculous meetings that waste time and add to the burden of working there; some particularly severe personalities that are barely able to hide their contempt for teachers; and more...

pros: Flexible environment.  Freedom of teaching. Nice facilities. Nice students. Most are already working people 30 years or older. I like the experience and would like to work for them again.
cons: No benefits for part-time jobs. Flexible environment.  Freedom of teaching. Nice facilities. Nice students. Most are already working people 30 years or older. I like the experience and would like to work for them again.

job_title: Military Enrollment Advisor in Phoenix, AZ
pros:
Benefits like free education (if they own the school)
Competitive salary
Work-life balance.
cons:
Most managers are so detached from employee procedures they can not answer employee questions without another employee to assist. 

Employees are often belittled. This includes senior management to middle management to employee.

Compensation is all about the sale. While the matrix focuses on may areas it is designed so that all areas are affected by numbers of new enrollments. 

What have you done for me today attitude.

review_title: Dont do it unless you need your education....
pros: You get your eduction waived if you dont have a bachelors or associates, then get your education and leave.  Your Masters and Phd are discounted but that is about it.  If you work in the BayArea then dont work there, if it is somewhere else then maybe you have a chance.
cons: They do not promote and develop their employees unless you are apart of one their clicks.  Especially if you are in the BayArea.

review_title: Overall positive but can be frustrating
pros: A good place to work in order to cost effectively grow professionally. Staff can take courses at almost no cost, so if you are interested in an advanced degree, working at UoPX while getting it is an effective approach.
cons:
There are a lot of silos within the University and if you get a job with the wrong group your experience might not be good. 

There needs to be a better system of rewarding performance.

review_title: Strong potential, limited ability to execute
pros: I worked for the University of Phoenix for nearly 8 years.  I worked in Arizona and in California in a variety of roles.  At the hub in Phoenix, the opportunities are excellent.  There are lots of openings, opportunities for creativity, movement up, down, and around.  It is one of Phoenix's largest employers and they gave me my first real chance to take care of my family after college.  The promotion to manager was one of the best things to happen to me.
cons: Much of the cons come from working at the Southern California ground campus. The two places (online and ground) are world's apart.  At the ground campus, I was switched from a salary position (read: flexible schedule) to an hourly position (read: rigid schedule).  The biggest issue with the ground campus specifically is the ego-maniacal, backwards, poisonous culture that exists.  The advancement opportunities are non-existent.  Thus, an individual must do more to personally satisfy hiring managers than what is reasonable at large companies.  The layoffs add to the stress.  The focus on hours, calls, and retention still exists despite government regulations to the contrary.  The money and the power allowed people to become more of who they were, which in the case of our leadership and staff, were people that would probably have difficult ever getting hired anywhere else.  My former manager now has 1 person working for them when there were 8.  It happened in six months.  I left the company in April and will never look back.

review_title: A great company for educational benefits, but enrollment focus is geared toward anyone that can breathe.
job_title: Senior Quality Assurance Analyst in Phoenix, AZ
pros: I originally liked feeling as though my role made a difference, as working in Tech Support was a great way to interface with students and provide them with the support they needed to get through school. The education benefits are great. The compensation has been good throughout my roles. I like the idea of the company values that are in place. I feel like all of my leaders actually cared about my well being and displayed that by helping me get time off when needed. I feel like the work-life balance, when in an hourly position, is decent.
cons:
I am diametrically opposed to the education model that UOP employs as a for-profit institution. Having talked to and listened to thousands of students over the years in my roles, I feel like a MAJORITY of them are being taken advantage of so that UOP can make money. They enroll people for online programs that have barely used a computer and the 'introductory workshop' is a poorly structured and doesn't help to really weed out people that shouldn't be in an online university. As such, it's not uncommon for students to get 2 -3 blocks in, withdrawing large student loan amounts, and then dropping out because they just can't handle the work. UOP doesn't require an ACT or SAT type standardized entry exam, and as such, anyone that breathes and can get student loans is a target, which contributes to my negative feelings about the organization.

Beyond all of that, I feel like the work life balance in an exempt (salary) position is less desirable than hourly. There are no profit sharing or bonus incentives to make you feel better about working 45+ hours a week, and as such, there are months where I make less hourly than I did in my last role. The workload in my department has been a mess for months, and director level management seems to simply looks at the numbers to say we don't need to back-fill the two team members that left last year, while everyone on the team is constantly asking when the workload will calm down due to a poor work-life balance.

The role itself used to feel like it mattered in the grand scheme of the student experience, but with feedback from floor agents advising that they never have a chance to review their quality scores, and that their managers barely coach them or help them out, it makes me feel like my role has virtually no impact on how agents can improve their performance.

review_title: Many changes, little improvement for employees
pros: The potential vacation time is decent once you've been employed there for a while.  Good pay and benefits if it's your first professional environment.
cons: Reduced compensation/review impact over time of changes in advisor positions.  The Enrollment advisor position was most affected by the organizational changes, reduced raises.. which has been a tele-sales position (in addition to the counseling, admin, etc roles).  This turns the position into most strictly a call center, with sales responsibilities, and without the compensation.  The management is micromanagement to make positions automated.

review_title: Decent place to work, if you are on the enrollment side of things
pros:
Good benefits
Decent pay
Decent chance to progress, if you work for it.
cons:
Pay was below average for IT
Extremely political - All about who you know, and who's rear you kiss.
Management is not open to suggestions from front line staff

pros: Great benefits, flexible lunch schedules, easy job. Tons of vacation time.
cons: There is no growth and the private, higher education sector is losing a lot of steam. There are shift bids every year that are based on performance and tenure. If you have a bad round you could be stuck working till 9 at night and every Saturday for a year.

job_title: Senior Enrollment Representative in Gilbert, AZ
pros: Great benefits and salary.  Awesome experience to help adult students find their passion and vision in life.
cons: UOP has had a few bumps in the road which has put pressure on management to increase enrollments, at all costs, loosing sight of their mission statement, student centric.

job_title: Senior Enrollment Advisor in Cincinnati, OH
pros: Our team was awesome and we worked to create a traditional university climate in a nontraditional environment.  Many employees earned advanced education credentials while employed. There are great database management tools and continuous trainings for employees interested vertical advancement.
cons: Conflicting priorities between earning profit and student success resulted in massive employment layoffs and workforce uneasiness.  Local campuses closed leaving mostly online classes as the primary platform.

job_title: Adjunct Online Instructor in Mountain House, CA
pros: I enjoy working with University of Phoenix as it allows me to work from home. I was able to begin teaching through UOP when I was laid off in 2009 from my academic publishing job. In the classroom at least online, they allow you to do a lot with your syllabus now and adding different materials. This allows for you as an instructor to bring in current news into your classroom. It helps keep the discussion relevant and interesting with your students.  I also believe at some point all online faculty will have a better relationship with any ground campuses that are nearby. I believe this is great for morale as well as able to have fellow colleagues that are close.
cons: I believe the slowness in bringing things down to the associates level.  I feel that we are the last to get things. We are still waiting to have the change over from the 9 weeks to the 5 weeks. I hope the change is coming soon. Also I think they also should have more online adjuncts who are working full time. I think this is a good idea as some of us enjoy teaching and want to do it full time.  When positions open, we should be the first people that are looked at for these positions and should not have to go through a special process. I believe these are some things that are being addressed by the new president. I hope change is coming soon so that more online adjuncts are kept around.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: The culture, at times, can be great. During my time at UOP, I made some good friends and have a lot of great memories.
cons: In order to make any move within the company, be prepared to play the office politics game. Opportunities for any movement are almost nonexistent if you do not play extremely well within the office politics game. If you want to put your head down and work, don't expect to go anywhere. Promotions are granted by favoritism.

pros: The people and the culture were fun. Decent entry level job to get some customer service/higher education experience.
cons: You can be very micromanaged and everything is tracked. It wasn't a good fit for me because I don't believe in for-profits and that everyone should go to college. We had to give everyone an opportunity even if we knew they probably wouldn't be successful and it only hurts the students in the end.

job_title: Senior Enrollment Advisor in Phoenix, AZ
pros:
The company is energetic and desires to be successful in the crumbling for-profit market

The other reps are really amazing people to work with.  

You will find some managers really do care about increasing your ability to have effective conversations with people.

Nice building to work at

The longer you are there the more autonomy you can earn
cons:
University of Phoenix earned it's stripes by hiring aggressive, highly talented sales people (former real estate agents, mortgage brokers, sales people) and then the industry was regulated and forced to adapt.  Because of this, there are a lot of middle-level managers that received battlefield promotions during the huge boom in students.  They received promotions due to their ability to enroll students and replicate that in other individuals with skill sets close to theirs.  This is great, if the environment still accepted aggressive sales tactics, but it does not.  What UOPx is left with at Middle-management are people who are behind the curve on leadership and personnel development; their is a lot of wasted talent at Enrollment Rep. level and pretty much zero possibility for advancement.  The company has shifted to a high level of micro management with a looming fear of being part of the next-wave of lay-offs.    

The salary is roughly on-par with other Universities, benefits are mediocre as well.  

If you want a place to work, get a free degree or two and bounce out to a career, this would be the place to go.

pros: This company has the means to provide great benefits and the added bonus of free education! They pay well and offer competitive incentives! It is fulfilling to assist students in obtaining their education and assisting them through the financial aspect of that.
cons: Being a finance advisor can be challenging due to the fact that finances is a sensitive subject. Students who do not manage their funds efficiently tend to blame the finance advisor for their lack of planning. The position requires redundant conversations. The information surrounding the federal guidelines and things of that nature can be overwhelming.

job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Tempe, AZ
pros:
Good benefits including paid tuition, health care, 401k match, etc.

Generous PTO with tenure.

Very talented and creative coworkers.

Room for career growth.
cons:
Seems to be in a constant state of downsizing due to declining enrollment numbers year after year. 

No guarantee at job stability or long term employment (anymore).

Decisions seem to be made without  any thought being given to them. Change for the sake of changing, not because it makes sense in a long term strategy.

review_title: Best place I have ever worked!
pros: There are many pros to working at University of Phoenix! Some of these include their benefits package, extensive training, many opportunities for career advancement, and brand recognition.
cons: There are not many cons. It is a high growth company, so there are many changes happening, so you have to be adaptable. There is some pressure in enrollment, but goals are attainable if you can sell.

pros:
Good benefits. 
Tuition waivers for all types of degrees and programs.
cons:
Salary
Extremely stressful
Escalated phone calls 
Collections
Management
"Career progression" model makes it extremely difficult to move up in company.
I worked for UOP for almost 3 years and was very disappointed. They bring people in by offering free education and a great experience. The truth is, this is not a good experience and there are limits to the tuition waivers they offer. (for example, you cannot take more than 5 graduate courses within a year.) Management is composed of uneducated people who moved up from being a telemarketer during the "golden days" of this company when sales (enrollment) were non-stop and everyone was a rock star on the phones. Unfortunately they have horrible leadership skills and your success is based on the friendship with him/her. As a Finance Advisor you are mostly dealing with people who have not paid for their tuition and therefore cannot continue with their program...in other words, collections. If you do not have excellent customer service skills or if you do not have patience for escalated phone calls with ignorant people then you will surely fail at this job. This is not an advising role as the job title makes you believe, this is still a sales and retention role. The company restructured their "career progression" model which made it practically impossible for anyone to move up to management or leadership role. If you plan on making a career in customer service or phone-based sales then this might be a good fit, otherwise stay away. You will not get any credible experience in either finance or advising.

review_title: Ok Pay, but not much work
job_title: Adjunct Online Instructor in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Consistent rules, straightforward policies, I work online which is a big plus. The university has come a long way in making sure the students are really enrolled to go to school, instead of just to collect financial aid, which used to be a problem a few years ago.
cons: There just isn't as much work as there used to be. I usually teach two classes at a time now, with a few breaks through the year.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Orleans, LA
pros: Great place to work; high level of collegiality. Going through a difficult patch since 2010 but taking the right steps to maintain accreditation and grow again
cons: Recent reductions in national campus and learning center footprint have created a sense of uncertainty about job stability and career prospects for employees

review_title: A HUGE LET DOWN FROM THE BEGINNING AND KNEW IN 2 WEEKS THIS WAS NOT THE JOB FOR ME!
pros:
Occasional Free Food, Decent Health Benefits

Food was ordered pretty regularly for meetings and anytime there were leftovers everyone was welcome to help themselves.  The health benefits are better than most but was steadily getting worse.  They use to offer free education for employees but they now put a cap on how much they will pay for employees to go to school with them.  The education is mediocre at best so they should want to give it away.  The students they recruit will never be hirable in the real world for the type of degrees they obtain.  It’s all about the money with University of Phoenix.  And yes, these are the Pros.....
cons:
Salary, Management, Lack of Advancement Opportunities, No Job Security

They offer and pay an extremely low salary to most employees and when you are hired they always talk up advancement opportunities but the truth is if you do not fit in with their "management click" you will go nowhere in the company.  People interview and apply for internal positions all the time and never move up.  Everyone comes to work wondering if they will have a job by the end of the day.  The company is extremely secretive about any changes until they happen.  Salary merit increase is a joke if you are not a manager.  No matter how hard you work it will never reflect in your pay.  In fact, you’re lucky if you even get salary review within 6 months of when you are due for one.  HR is a joke! Do not turn to them for assistance for anything.  If your paycheck didn’t come, their response "Oh Well!"

review_title: Excellent leadership and management team throughout most of my time at the university.
job_title: Senior Enrollment Advisor in Phoenix, AZ
pros:
Financially rewarding if willing to work hard and if willing to learn and develop professionally. That is okay with me.
Great benefits; including tuition waiver.
cons: There are things beyond an advisor's control; higher education in the for-profit industry has been challenging for a number of years.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Great pay... used to be a great place to work
cons: NO decision making skills from executive management. They let go of GREAT employees based on criteria that makes no sense. They are so high up in their offices to give a crap about everyone below them

job_title: Senior Academic Counselor in Phoenix, AZ
pros: good starter position for education, help students if have skills to do so, free education, good people to work with in a very easy work environment compared to other corporations
cons: management doesn't have power to promote from within and changes happen too often based on leadership that is disconnected from the reality of the business platform. need more managers with actual management skills

pros: They support their faculty. There are plenty of training opportunities. The on campus provides more support because it's face to face. Employee stock optons.
cons: The pay. They are the lowest paying online university. You only get a raise every few years. You don't get enough consistent classes. No benefits.

review_title: Fall of the Empire or a new Renaissance?
pros:
- In these troubling times where employers are beginning to either lower or remove benefits from employees due to Obamacare - UOP still offers solid benefits such as medical, dental, vision, 401k, etc. 
- Another positive is that they are still the largest private University and with that comes the ability to  sometimes "call the shots" often with external stakeholders. 
- Another positive is the University is moving toward a much more employable Degrees and Certifications = Jobs model for gainful employment. This is an excellent approach given our jobs market & economy the past 8+ years has been the worst overall in the history of the United States.
cons:
-Mostly poor management in terms of their ability to listen or care about front line employees and a huge disconnect with understanding of internal processes due to ego and/or unwillingness to work or learn "in the trenches." 
-Rapid change, turnover
-Loss of "Brain Capital" over the past 5-10 years of layoffs & combined with good employees leaving
-Sometimes difficult to promote in some positions due to lack of a career path or inability to apply to middle or upper management positions without a Doctoral level position.

job_title: Student Services Manager in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Great people who are motivated to support students and help them fulfill their education goals.
cons: Directors of operations and upper level leaders are disconnected and unrealistic. They tend to re-use tactics to retain and reclaim students even though the tactics may have failed miserably. The tactics get renamed and introduced as the latest and greatest but employees quickly recognize the tactics and become frustrated.

pros: The company believes in helping employees obtain a work-life balance. They provide flexible schedules as well as employee assistance programs. The company also provides tuition assistance. I found my managers to be individuals who strive for excellence and are ethical.
cons: The company has experienced a large drop in customers which has impacted revenue. Decisions on how to handle the decrease has caused a decrease in customer service. Additionally, there is no much loyalty toward long-time employees and little room for advancement.

pros: Was a short commute, flexible schedule, ability to work from home.
cons: Lack of direction, leadership not engaged,  lack of communication, very high turnover, questionable reputation outside business community.

pros:
University of Phoenix is embracing Lean Agile practices and is implementing SAFe. This is being supported from the top down, including University President.
We have new IT leadership that is bringing new technology.  Training is being provided and our technologists are learning new skills.  Life/Work balance is great.
cons: A lot of changes have been introduced in the past year and sometimes communication isn't as good as it could be.

pros: The school provides a great avenue for busy working professionals to increase their ability to be  providing a variety of educational methods, such as online and on campus. The employees go out of their way to ensure students are getting the assistance they need to be successful (i.e. tutoring, writing classes).
cons: The Leadership teams run this like a call center where they need to meet their enrollment goals and do not care how they reach them. The company culture is at odds with the management method.

job_title: Enrollment Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: UOPX was a very collaborative environment. It was great to work with so many unique individuals and learn and grow from one another. It is a fast paced environment, continuously identifying ways to be innovative and different. Student -centric mentality.
cons: Lots of organizational change and restructure the past few years, for the business approach of the University. Change is good, but at times it came to rapidly and it was difficult to keep up.

review_title: Being on the team at University of Phoenix has been the most wonderful career experience.
pros:
Amazing professional development.
Compassionate enrollment managers and very caring senior managers. 
Career progression program is firmly in place, and coaching is always positive.
cons:
Salary is on the low end at $42,000 with a Masters Degree.  If it were only $9,000; I would never leave. 
Review for raises are only yearly, with no exceptions.  
Can[t transfer to higher department till you are six months at current position.

job_title: Senior Enrollment Advisor in Sacramento, CA
pros: Standard benefits are competitive, the best part is the 52% discount on your education and $5250 in fees waived annually.  Your education at the bachelors level is waived with the exception of the resource fee.
cons: Strong sales environment despite behavior based performance management.  No opportunity for advancement and change is constant. The organization makes all decisions with profitability as the primary motivator.  As a result employee morale has been compromised leading to many resignations.

pros: The ability to share life experiences. Motivate students for their future and make a difference in their lives personally and professionally. Does not rely on books but on sharing each others work experiences.
cons: Pay not commensurate with volume of class work to be done. Average class is 15-20 plus students . You get paid approximately $50 per student in a 5 week class. Classes meet 3 times a week  which means you get paid approximately $3 per session. Each session is 3-4 hours which equates to less than $1 per hour..

review_title: At least I got a free, somewhat of an, Education
pros:
You only have to pay like $40 a class.
You are able to get OT.  Well, at least you were able to get OT
cons: A lot of pressure to collect money, retain students and go way above and beyond without any recognition or compensation for your efforts.

review_title: Overall grateful for the experience and opportunity.
job_title: Campus Operations Manager in San Diego, CA
pros: An open environment for new initiatives and projects. Work closely with students and staff to supplement retention and career development. Manage and support staff to ensure positive student interactions and student success.
cons: Common middle management stressors including being directly responsible for team results, while also delivering disciplinary actions when needed. Some evening hours are required. No raises or bonuses. Growth is available only when new positions open up.  Sometimes limited by corporate policies and metrics.

review_title: Not a place to build a career
job_title: Financial Services Representative in Phoenix, AZ

cons: Too many technology issues, frequent layoffs, no upward mobility, high-stress customer service environment, a lot of red tape in financial services.  Customer facing representatives can expect to have little to no authority or autonomy in day to day responsibilities.

job_title: Student Services Coordinator in Rancho Cordova, CA
pros: The pay is fair and for the most part everyone gets along really well and it is a fun and inspiring environment to work in. Being around student is always fun, but Phoenix does offer a lot of staff events and other things to keep the ir employees motivated.
cons: There is not a lot of room for growth. The other issue is that a lot of their campuses are closing so you do not really have job security.

review_title: Great Student Experience, Disappointing Company Experience
pros:
Able to make a difference in peoples lives
Help people make positive change
Work with great people - they hire awesome employees
cons:
Dishonest regarding job requirements
Inadequate training
Telemarketing sales environment
Dishonest about earning potential as well as Growth potential
Mentally abusive environment 
Lack of care for employees - old and new

review_title: Used to be great - not anymore
pros: Sevearl opportunities for growth, generous tuition discount, good pay

Senior management is desperate and it shows in the decision-making over the past few years - i.e., closing profitable campuses and keeping the low performing ones open. Suspect the university will be a small, Phoenix-only university within the next 5-10 years.

pros:
Great benefits
Education is excellent and definitely worth it for employees who take advantage of the benefits.
cons: Leadership is driving the company into the ground. Lots of favoritism and good ole boy culture. Good luck surviving layoffs. No one is safe there. Long term outlook bleak.

job_title: Senior Account Executive-Team Lead in Chicago, IL
pros: Benefits, pay, and coworkers are great. Opportunity to increase and finish your education is wonderful.
cons: Senior Leadership has no direction, playing reactionary to situations instead of action oriented. Mid level leadership is directionless and some should not be in roles as they don't have leadership skills. No clear pathway for growth, and no clear direction for staff to follow.

pros: I've been here a very long time.  It's been great for most of my years.  The benefits are good, pay is more than decent.
cons: Lately, it's just plain bad.  They don't know whether they are a call center or a university, and they are paying for past mistakes overall. It's insane.  Technology is so old and procedures so complicated, it's like they set you up for failure.  Every phone call is an opportunity to totally screw up something important and it's the combination of bad technology and incredibly long and complex procedures and practices that does it.  Nobody is steering the ship, so the odds that this will change soon is zip.

review_title: Great tuition, health, and vacation benefits; little job security

pros: Good compensation and workload was managable if you were willing to out in the effort. Pay and insurance were reasonable in comparison to competitors.
cons: A lot of politics in upper management and the company is losing students so there were several continued layoffs throughout the company. Hard to move up the chain of command unless you had an "in" with upper management.

review_title: Sad decline of University of Phoenix
pros: Online teaching - done anywhere and anytime.
cons:
Worst pay in CA for teaching online
No pay raise in 15 years,  and recent reduction in faculty pay to $18hr!
No recognition for advanced degrees in pay 
Too many students in a classroom (over 40)
Curriculum looks  like a diploma mill

job_title: Senior Quality Assurance Analyst in Phoenix, AZ
pros: I have worked at the University for 5 years. The employees are friendly. Obtaining a degree is basically free, you have to pay a resource fee of $80 a class but this is virtually nothing. They pay relatively well.
cons: Nothing to say, I have worked here for 5 years and feel like I am stuck in the position I am in now. Management is never fired no matter how horrible they are.

pros: One of the few places where you can teach with a Masters Degree, rather than a Doctorate Degree. Teaching can be rewarding when students put forth the effort. Faculty have some flexibility in scheduling classes, although often requests to teach were very last minute.
cons: My local area campus (Detroit) was very disorganized. Students were unprepared for college, expected to get their degree too easily, and did not read/study for class. Faculty were expected to clock in and out - I have never been asked to do that before!

job_title: Military Enrollment Advisor in Phoenix, AZ
pros: The job itself can be very rewarding.  You meet a lot of great people and it can be a fun work environment.
cons: I worked there during a transition phase when they had done away with the cash bonuses for enrollments.  There were a lot of employees who weren't happy about it and there was also a hiring freeze so advancement opportunity was not great.

pros: It's a big company so they tend to offer a lot of jobs for hire. They office environment is good, amenities available to employees is good
cons: Your job function will frequently change.. Leadership is not very good. Conflicting direction. Most of all, they do not have any care much about the employees. I have witness countless rounds of layoffs in the past 2 years. 1,000's of employees..No communication on what is going on. A lot of change. They burn and churn employees like candy.. I would not trust them with any kind of loyalty.

pros: Higher than average salary in Central Florida area; the people I worked with were fun and gave me cause to go to work; the mission was very inspiring (to bring higher education to those who would otherwise be excluded); the educational benefits were great!
cons: Higher education in for-profit sector has been shrinking for years; the organization micro-managed and was top-heavy; for an organization that had many people devoted to strategic planning, it didn't see the big hole that it walked into...

review_title: Good opportunity if self motivated but must be disciplined
job_title: Enrollment Counselor in Long Beach, CA
pros: Fun work environment and noble work.  Good feeling to help students get back on track and especially rewarding to see them at graduation.  Priceless feeling!
cons: Long hours and lack of work/life balance.  Preassure for constant goals... Not always compensated for work put in, but if you have high numbers, potential to make very good salary.  Plus, overtime pd even though positions are salary

pros: Easy job, easy hours. Can ask for certain shifts if that suits you best. This is a decent place to work if you just want to get by and have pretty good benefits.
cons: They are a corporation and make lots of money but they try to act like a "school" when it benfifts them..like when determining salaries. The pay is pathetic.

pros: It was a pleasant company to work for. Worked there just over a year. The company went through many changes which I thought were very positive for both the employees and the students the university serviced. They offered many outside activities and group based activities to keep students engaged. Also, there was constant training that equipped employees.
cons: Not much upward mobility. Sometimes the job security was not there.

pros: You can work from home for the majority of the class, and spend only 4 hours a week in the classroom. You can teach up to 2 classes at a time as associate faculty.
cons: Many local campuses are closing as the company will refocus on online efforts. Would be nice if Phoenix supplied new faculty with more material for class times, such as Power Point slides, suggested agendas, etc.

pros:
Continuous faculty development
Involves faculty in all areas such as course design and new classroom platform
Has formal faculty recognition program
cons:
Too many vice presidents and no one knows what they do except praise each other
Appoints faculty to teach courses without experience in content/subject matter
Arrogance sensed by VPs during faculty meetings
Some deans need to go to pasture/outdated thinking/clinging to learning theory not current

pros:
-Education reimbursement (100%) after 6 months of full time employment
-Competitive wages on sign on
-main campus is easy to get to from all parts of the valley
-fantastic health benefits options (almost all major carriers have 3 plans available for you to choose from)
cons:
-Recent transition from public to private, currently experiencing some transition pains
-IT dept is going through a transition, old CIO left, new CIO is very different and has big plans
-due to previous financial troubles, merit increase rate and schedule is currently halted or unclear

review_title: Great place to be - 5 years ago....
job_title: Enrollment Manager in Jersey City, NJ
pros: Great training, development, sales skills, free degree.
cons: Little growth from within, lots of people being transferred in to take over positions. Leadership lost touch with the day to day. Compensation changes went from reviews every 6 months to once a year with a 3% increase, maybe. If you want to hire educational sales counselors, you need to pay them what they are worth in the market.

review_title: Great environment to work, great education, poor executive management
job_title: Academic Affairs Supervisor in Charlotte, NC
pros: The nature of the work and ability to help others achieve a higher education is both noble and rewarding.
cons: Veyr porrly managed company. Always making changes to systems and way things are done. employees never have chance to get used to one thing before another change is made. Also too centrally controlled.

pros: Easy job, rewarding interactions with students, plenty of schedule options, decent health benefits and paid time off, tuition discounts for masters program
cons: Constant threat of layoffs, inept coworkers outside of the enrollment department that negatively affect your job, ZERO opportunities for advancement, and recently just a doom and gloom culture

pros: There are a lot of great people who work there. They also offered a pretty decent benefits package and paid vacation time.
cons: A lot of change in every single department which affects the entire company and its operating procedures.  Advancement to management is possible if you are willing to play office politics.

review_title: A wonderful place for new hires, and the job is very rewarding.
pros: The campus is very newly remodeled and there is a lot of opportunity for education and life long learning skills. The on boarding process is amazing and they welcome everyone with open arms.
cons: The organization as a whole is going through many changes, and it's difficult to feel safe in the position because of the annual layoffs.

pros: Benefits, decent pay, tuition waiver, employees, holiday parties.  I received a free master's degree that propelled me into my current career.
cons: None that I can remember.  I had a manager once that I did not get along with.  They used to have pay decreased, but they abolished that years ago.

review_title: My time at the University of Phoenix has been great.  I have been able to meet people all over the world
pros: The online faculty positions offer a great deal of flexibility.  You can attend/teach a class from any computer with an internet connection. The human resources department does all that it can to resolve problems for faculty members.
cons: On of the greatest challenges of working here is the fact that you are always online. Providing feedback to students can also take about 10-15 hours per week.

job_title: Adjunct Online Instructor in Denver, CO
pros: Ability to work at home and schedule my own hours.  I liked the students and, for the most part, they were excited about the subjects and receptive to feedback.  There were good training opportunities to build instructional skills.
cons: There was a gradual decline in the number of classes offered to instructors, with no communication or explanation why.  Some instructors would report teaching 4 classes simultaneously while others had one class.

pros: The hours were fine, there were no quotas, fine benefits and pay as well, would recommend to anyone if they were hiring.
cons: Sometimes mundane, but that's the nature of the job.  We went through a lot of training when some of it felt like it could be learned in the job.

review_title: Management makes this a horrid place to work as an Enrollment Counselor
pros: Vacation and sick time, paid holidays, and good benefits. Nice building and cafeteria. 1 hour lunch
cons: Micro managed, crappy leads, bait and switch. I was told in my interview that it wasn't a sales position and that's exactly what it is.

pros: The pros are that you are able to teach from a remote location. The students are respectful and enthusiastic about learning.
cons: The cons are that the courses are developed and there is little flexibility in the curriculum. You often feel like a grading robot.

review_title: Bad pay, incompetent management, but free college.
pros: 100% Associates, Bachelors or Masters Degree tuition reimbursement to attend at University of Phoenix, regular catered food, no pre-employment drug screening.
cons: "Pride", horrible pay scale, little to no room for advancement, incompetent managers/leadership who also continue to hire incompetent employees and wonder why nothing works, budget is never done right leaving only money for "Enrollment" (sales reps) and extravagant marketing campaigns. Bottom line isn't the student and their educational achievements.

job_title: Senior Enrollment Advisor in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Pay was fair for just sitting around talking people into school. The DOE was starting to crack down on methods of enrollment.
cons: Starting to get hit with layoffs and government sanctions for enrollment and use of Financial Aid. If you can find another place to work then do it, but this could be a last resort type place.

pros:
independence of facilitating classes
wide range of materials to support facilitating the classes
flexibility of when to engage with students
good feedback from University about offering feedback and encouragement to students
cons:
large class size
not much in the way of salary for the large class size
quite a bit of paperwork required to run the classes given the large number of students in the classes

job_title: Senior Enrollment Representative, Team Leader in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Freedom to grow while making mistakes with supportive management at regional level. Great team mates also makes the day go by faster.
cons: The fast pace sometimes leaves one's head spinning. For that , one can adjust appropriately. Upper management often struggles to provide clear goals that align with the University's mission and values statements.

job_title: Full Time Faculty in Tempe, AZ
pros: The people on the front lines are incredibly hard working.
cons: Everything else: management, upper management, corporate culture, job positions. I spent 10 years of my life at UoPhx in positions ranging from enrollment (worst), academic affairs, payroll, and ending as a Full-time Faculty. I was unceremoniously swept up in mass layoffs because, apparently, specially trained faculty are not valued. Poor students.

pros: Working with great people, free coffee, and a lot of great feedback for performance improvement.
cons: If you were away from your desk you were questioned why. They wanted us planted in our seats and we had to clock in and out every time we got up for a cup of coffee or to use the restroom.

review_title: If you can make it here...you can make it anywhere
pros:
LOTS of training
Professional polishing
Benefits are great (free tuition, medical, dental, 401k)
Great network of people,
Opportunities to advance in nationally
cons:
Too small to advance quickly locally
low morale at times of change
too much in-fighting amongst departments
management incompetence etc.

pros: Great benefits package!  Tuition discount! Friendly coworkers!
cons: Managers and upper management guidlines are inconsistent throughout the University.  What is okay for one division is not okay for another with upper management changing rules.  Negative attitude and individuals in management out for themselves.

job_title: Call Center Specialist in Phoenix, AZ
pros:
The pay is decent
Great benefits (free tuition)
Chance ti meet new people
cons: Majority of management sucks!! Bunch if literal ass kissers who got their position by doing just that. When they get there they forget their humble beginnings and stick their noses in the air. They suck at giving realistic constructive critisism. Every week there are new policies and why is everyone forever changing seats?!

review_title: I enjoyed waking up and going to my work.
job_title: Admissions Intake Specialist in Phoenix, AZ
pros:
I was not micromanaged so much.  As long as I did my job, I was able to take lunch when I wanted, or my breaks when I wanted.
Our team had frequent  meetings for updates, and a few for some team builders as well.
cons: Our department moved a lot, In the 3.5 yrs I was there, we moved to 3 different buildings, and in the last one, we had to move to different cubicles 4 times!

job_title: Outbound Contact Specialist in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Extremely easy phone job. Training lasted a week but everything needed could have been covered in one day. Calling college leads. Non-sales enviroment. Free school for all employees.
cons: 6 Month wait to take advantage of school. A lot of employees don't seem to take advantage. Some supervisors don't seem to bright. Feels like typical "outsource" call center. Current  problem with Accreditation.

pros: With the University of Phoenix, you get a free college education. They cover 100% of tuition. You only pay a technology or resource fee for each class. They pay well, have a comfortable culture, and emphasize team building.
cons: There is a lot of emphasis on sales, regarding of the position in which you get hired. Even a finance counselor is expected to recruit new students and boost the bottom line.

job_title: Senior Enrollment Advisor in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Parent company Apollo group provides numerous opportunities in an array of business fields. University of Phoenix provides training and mentoring for employees seeking advancement and growth in management.
cons: Changes in the industry have forced recent downsizing. The university now requires Bachelors degrees for a number of positions. Still, from a business standpoint this can be seen as a positive as well.

pros: The opportunity for advancement is amazing. 100% jealous free environment; in fact, management reviews include how management has helped their teams advance in the company.
cons: I was working there about 10 years ago when the economy began crashing.  We went from 100% feeling of job security to being afraid to speak our mind because the company was downsizing.

review_title: OK pay for the work, not bad hours, good benefits.  Poor politics and lots of red tape.
pros:
The University has some great ethics and morals and principles.
Because they are For Profit the salary is great.
cons: Publicly traded and For Profit (Sales and Politics).  Unbalanced in salary compensation in many of the departments for identical work.

pros: Cutting edge higher educational systems, processes, and concepts. Generally good culture and worthwhile benefits and future advancement potential.
cons: For-profit higher education is changing dramatically to meet the evolving demands of the market and various regulatory mandates. Be prepared to be highly flexible and possibly have your position reclassified, restructured or even eliminated depending on the needs of the various colleges within the university.

pros: Flexable schedule, training was good and left me feeling confident in my job, room to grow with the company, benefits package
cons: Some of the goals that you are rated on are hard to achieve, sometimes totally out of your hands, room to grow but it often felt like a popularity contest when it came to upper management taking new managers.

review_title: Good job but lacking upward mobility
pros: Great working environment,  stellar education benefits, leadership supports customer facing roles very well, most employees care a great deal about brand and product ( Pride)
cons: big company that is shrinking in size means that growing into a management or director position is nearly impossible, department of education changes policies frequently which can greatly impact merit-based compensation

review_title: This was the hardest job I have ever had.
pros:
Good team environment.
Education benefits covered.
cons:
Constantly calling people even though they have told you they are not interested.
Ridiculously long work hours.
Sitting in the same spot for said long hours on a phone the whole time.  
People yelling at you because they told someone else they weren't interested and instead of taking them off the contact list, they are shuffled over to a new person, usually the newly hired.

review_title: Great Job for Part Time Instructors
job_title: Certified Advanced Facilitator in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Very flexible schedule for asynchronous classroom, allowing instructors to work a full time job at another company while facilitating classes outside of normal business hours.  Compensated training for senior part time faculty via an annual cash bonus.
cons: The training and course materials can be unengaging but this is not a significant criticism.  Each new version of the online classroom and course materials has been an improvement over the previous version.

review_title: Terrific place to work.  Always evolving and they take pride in leading the online educational revolution.
pros: They work hard to provide adequate training and all necessary resources to fell comfortable doing your job.
cons: None really, I only left due to a family relocation.  They set clear daily expectations...their expectations are high and you will work hard, but for any decent person those expectations are certainly attainable.

pros: Flexibility to work anytime from anywhere.  You are offered sessions and you can accept or decline at will (as long as you teach 1 session per year).  Yearly pay increase.  Some flexibility in making the syllabus.
cons: Pay is low for the amount of work done.  Actual learning/retention/application don't seem to be a priority.  Must have current work experience in the field of study - inconvenient for those looking for a work-from-home career.

job_title: Executive Enrollment Representative/Manager in Phoenix, AZ
pros:
Great health and vacation/sick time benefits
Plenty of training opportunities
Great education benefits
Recognized monthly in awards events in performing above expectations.
cons:
Lack of growth potential
Instability within the organization
Schedule is based on tenure and performance, making it difficult for newer employees to get a preferred schedule.
No potential to get raises based on performance

job_title: Senior Academic Counselor in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Coworkers are great, you might even make friends outside of work. Most managers are friendly and help you improve in your role. Training is thorough and constant. Pay is higher than other colleges.
cons: Stability. Declining enrollment so there is the threat of layoff constantly. Pay isn't performance based, so you get the same raise, if any, as everybody else. Some managers can be nitpicky about your calls. Hard  to move up.

pros: Our mission is amazing and you can tell our employees truly love to help our students.  The University is very invested in the employee experience and listens then takes action on employee feedback.
cons: I can tell that not every department has a great employee experience yet but I does appear that every department is trying to improve.

job_title: Military Enrollment Advisor in Phoenix, AZ
pros: great benefits, sick and vacation time. The company is generally good, and has great intentions to help students and be a positive influence on the community and its students...
cons: lower pay than most universities, no incentives, little to no upward mobility, the company will release new plans that are not thought out clearly and they end up doing more harm than good, or they retract the plan later and confuse the employees.

pros: It is a steady job that you can count on. If you want a low paying but stable job then this might be it. The best "Pro" is semi-free schooling.
cons: They discourage innovative thinking and do not empower employees. Managers are no more than supervisors and the leadership team barely trusts their employees. The pay is terrible and have made it clear that there is little to no chance of advancing.

pros:
Great company with good core values
A company that pushes compliance and ethics
Starting pay is decent.
Yearly pay increases 
Generous earned leave
Holiday pay / opportunity for overtime
Work hours are flexible
Good people to work with  
Health Benefits
Employee tuition assistance / reimbursement
The company is good to it's employees
cons:
Enrollment Reps. bids for shifts based on seniority. It seems hard to move up in the company, people seem to stay at the same level and job for years.

Wish more positions were created for advancement.

pros: Good work schedule, clean working environment, great benefits, doing the right thing opposed to other universities, they are trying to do what is best for the students and will get there one day.
cons: Unfortunately there have been a lot of lay-offs, not a good compensation plan, no one knows what the other department is doing, leadership id constantly changes, employees evaluations are not beneficial.

job_title: Senior Enrollment Advisor in Tempe, AZ
pros: Great place for networking, increasing skills and loads of content for learning. Their degree programs are on target and the block style classes include the fast paced, convenient learning environment that is included in tuition. Education benefits are great!
cons: Every layoff has its advantages, however, instead of correcting the problematic employees (many of them being managers and directors), upper management prays on the enrollment, finance and academic advisers. Slim to no change for career opportunities and they will not be contributing to 401K's.

job_title: Adjunct Online Instructor in Olympia, WA
pros: UofP is a great school to get your foot in the door with if you need a bottom tier school to begin with, or at least, they were. They offer some unique electives so if you teach less popular fields like religion you may have a shot.
cons: The school has gone through major changes in learning platform and leadership, and the pay is not good.  Of course, the name is not great either, and something they need to overcome.

pros: Its the Best online scholl with a great online system
cons: Micromanagement it is all about sales

pros: they pay for your degree but if you don't sell as much as they want you to they take the benefit away
cons: excessive favoritism, disrespectful management, very difficult to advance, no real say or control in your work environment or approach towards the customer.  Very high pressure sales, training not adequate for actual work performed once you hit the sales floor.

review_title: Bearable if you want a free education.
pros: Free/discounted tuition for employees, gym and cafe on-site, good healthcare benefits and decent pay.
cons: Upper management makes decisions that negatively impact both employees and students.  They are so far removed that I don't think they understand the impact of the changes they make.  Severe lack of communication about changes.  Lack of appropriate training.

review_title: Great place to work if you enjoy selling.
pros: Good benefits. Full tuition waiver starting on day 1. Fun, call-center type atmosphere. Made some great friends while I was there. Education is important, and people that thrive with this company are passionate about helping others through higher education. Opportunity to advance quickly if you achieve your quota.
cons: Pressure to achieve a sales quota. Can't transfer to another position that is more fitting to your skills unless you are achieving in your current position.

review_title: Leaves a lot to be desired
job_title: Enrollment Advisor in Jersey City, NJ
pros: Good training, great people.  There is a lot to be learned about customer service and asking good questions to reveal answers.
cons: Constant change to the point that you're unsure about job responsibilities, shifting hours, training can be a bit invasive, and a boss interrogated me and accused me my personal life was the reason I couldn't ask better questions….

pros: Great people, Dr. Sperling's vision and mission have helped millions achieve their goals. I believed in the brand 2 years ago.
cons: Present leadership is shameful and lacks vision, integrity, experience, passion for UOP's original mission. Now it's all about profit ...not about staff or students.

pros: Excellent students, great environment.  The classes consist of adult learner who are ready to learn.
cons: One is not assured of class.  It depends on student registration.  Most classes are given to certain professors that are close to the dean.

pros:
The focus to the students is excellent.  Quality educational experience and student outcomes is the focus.
The recent sale has many unknown questions for the future.
cons: Senior & executive leadership is not connected to the employees.  Five years of random downsizing and layoffs has created a culture of mistrust.  Attitudes is that leadership doesn't take any hits.

job_title: Senior Enrollment Representative in Phoenix, AZ
pros: LOVE LOVE LOVE Education and the HIGHER EDUCATION INDUSTRY.  UOP has been my platform to success from it's beginning rise via NASDAQ.
cons: Company has completely changed the role of the consultative sales approach.  All call center mentality.  It is a call center now and the representatives are now required to sit at their desk and handle all outbound call center calls.

pros: Good people, competitive pay,  3 weeks PTO, work from home allowance, seldom work overtime.
cons: Lackluster benefits, layer upon layer of decision makers, slow moving & risk averse culture.

review_title: University of Phoenix is an awesome place to work!
job_title: Senior Enrollment Advisor in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Positive work enviroment, pleanty of support from co-workers on up.  All most all upper management started as enrollment advisor, therefore they have a tremendous understanding of my position plus I think it benefits our students in the type of service they receive.
cons: Can't really come up with one and I have been with the University more than 5 yrs.

job_title: Adjunct Professor in San Antonio, TX
pros: Smaller class sizes than most brick and mortar schools, which gives you more opportunity to give individual attention to students. Lots of training opportunities to hone your skills.
cons: teaching rotation is hard to see. They change standards and methods often and is it can hamper teaching. No possibility to transfer to a new place or to continue teaching if you move and return. Placed back into a non-teacher's roll as if you never taught for them before.

review_title: I worked at UOP for 4 1/2 years and it was OK.
pros: Free Tuition and gained great work experience. Had a GREAT manager right before leaving all others either did not know what they were doing, did nothing, or created unnecessary busy work.
cons: Crummy senior management. They're always introducing new offers in attempt to retain students however it almost seems like they just trying anything and everything to find something that works. Can be a bit frustrating. Also NO opportunity for growth.

job_title: Admissions Advisor in West Hempstead, NY
pros: The company offers extensive resources and support that ensure the success of the employees. The best part of this role is to help students with the enrollment process and to share their accomplishment when they graduate.
cons: Due to the size of the organization you never get to meet most of the employees and it can be a challenge for advancement.

pros: Free education (for what the value of a UofP degree is worth) Free coffee, ice, and water. This used to be a great place to work but executive missteps have changed the culture for the worse.
cons: Change, change, and more change. No value given to rank and file employees. Zero empowerment to do the right thing on the behalf of students by management. No more opportunity for growth.

pros: They are finally paying faculty for training and meetings that they are required to attend.
cons: They allow students to dictate which work they will submit and side with the students against the faculty in every instance. Their constantly moving benchmarks and lack of leadership lead to increasingly dissatisfied adjuncts. Their platform used to be state of the art, it no longer is.This is also evident in their declining enrollment. The school offers a lack of training for faculty. I was an faculty member for 6 years before I was ever contacted by someone from the school.

job_title: Enrollment Counselor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: If you like sales and are a motivational person, then this just might be the job for you. The title for this postion should be "Sales Representative" and not Enrollment Counselor. You are basically a sales person with a "counselor" disguise.
cons: The managers are not fair. If they do not like you, they find any excuse to let you go. Explains why some people in this position remained at their jobs for years, even though they were incompetent.

review_title: Easy job but no opportunities to grow
pros: If you are looking for a steady job with 40 hours, you will find it here. The opportunity to work full time and go to school to earn your degree is definitely here.
cons: There is nowhere for you to go, management opportunities are slim and even the option to make additional money is almost abandoned altogether.

pros: Great training in various industries (Healthcare, education, business, technology, social sciences, etc), higher ed, fin aid, accreditation, etc. Employees bond over the shared dissent they have for the upper management.
cons: Underpaid workforce. A lot of responsibility for a little bit of money. Clueless, incompetent management who fail to take responsibility. Favors Mormon believers.

pros: Helping students achieve their goals is rewarding; your days go by fast because you are always busy; we have excellent software to help manage our workload; tuition benefits are amazing
cons: Micromanagement is common; not very many opportunities to move up in position; executives and senior leadership are out of touch with front-line staff needs and wants;

job_title: Enrollment Advisor in South Jordan, UT
pros: Was able to help students with getting their careers going which was rewarding.  Decent benefits package.  Great benefit on tuition reduction.
cons: Their is no chance for raises or promotions.  The company is slowly dying and moving everything to online and is continually downgrading staff.  Company has no respect for their employees.  I was fired without any cause and i'm not just saying that.  They literally couldn't tell me why is was being let go.  really low morals for a corporation.

review_title: This has by far been the best company to work for.
job_title: Student Finance Advisor in Scottsdale, AZ
pros: The salary is comparable to the cost of living. The availablty to increase by salary was attainable and the training my experience there feel that I was prepared to handle anything.
cons: The role of a Financial Aid advisor can be very stressful so the day to day duties can be quite daunting. I really didnt have any issues with this company.

review_title: I had the opportunity to work with a fantastic group of campus faculty dedicated to the students and their learning.
pros: The pay was good, each class was accelerated and ran for five or six weeks. Faculty had academic freedom in the classroom and was provided with support.
cons: Some students needed remedial resource for some content areas because of the length of time since they last attended school.

review_title: College Degree to be a Call Center Worker
pros: The job is fairly easy and very task oriented if you enjoy knowing what you are coming into every day.
cons: The job is a call center position.  You work with service crews.  You're lunch break is assigned to you.   You get in trouble if you miss answering a call.   You have no control over the students fate

pros: Great pay at the time if you worked very hard and smart at your job.  Extremely enjoyable to help adult students achieve their goals.
cons: The company reacted to regulation changes in a way that penalized the employees that were making the organization the most money, which was dissapointing as a top performer for years.  Also, the company had no training in place for Managers.

pros: The pay was good, education benefits are nice. There are some great reps that really know their stuff. Teams become more like families.
cons: The company is not very stable, never know when the next lay off is coming. Shift bids don't allow those with less tenure early shifts. Everything changes! Company is going downhill.

pros:
-My subordinates and people working as my peers were amazing, talented people.
-Great education benefits.
-Amazing amounts of vacation earned.
cons:
-After 5 years of layoffs, remaining personnel is more less the low hanging fruit.  Hungry, motivated, talented people have for the most part left.
-The morale and outlook are at their lowest points in my 9 years there.
-Now ability to grow and progress professionally there in any capacity.

pros: The people that I worked with were amazing.
cons: Really difficult to get promoted, company was more concerned about bottom line and didn't focus enough on their people.  Salary was far too low

pros: free college, flex hours, relaxed atmosphere, good raises
cons: you have to work in a room full of people in cubicles

review_title: Working for this company right now is a bit of a rollercoaster ride.
pros: Pay was ok, good benefits,great co-workers
cons: Very poor leadership, managers do not know how to manage change, leadership has not figured out how to manage for performance with the new regulations set in place. Poor leadership is pushing out talented workers.

pros: The job is easy and flexible
cons: You have to do all of the work of a salesmen with none of the benefits.  There is no commission.  There is no way in the world to move up anymore.  They are constantly firing people.  The size of the University is shrinking because the industry has changed.  Management is trying to change with the industry but they are all filled withe people who are in charge because they were promoted for performing well within the old system.  This ship is sinking.  Do not take a job here, you will regret it.

review_title: A chance to change people's lives

review_title: Complete downward spiral and in disarray
pros: Co-workers are a blessing. I've developed some great friendships. Reduced cost for going to school, but I'll discuss that more.
cons:
Utter chaos. This has become the titanic and all they are doing is picking the music the quartet plays on the deck while people search for lifeboats (new jobs). EVERY DAY there is a new metric, or duty, or approach to get people to enroll, and do whatever they can to make students stick around and keep paying for school. This school is no longer the best online school option, and they were never the cheapest. The classes can be moved around at will and the lack of conformity between instructors creates a diminished development experience. 

And now I have to explain to prospective students how "we are accredited, but we have been put on notice wit the Higher Learning Commission" which means in the future your diploma may be toilet paper. Does Michigan, or ASU, or Duke, or Rutgers have to worry about accreditation? Hell no!

The new Get to Work or whatever the stupid catch phrase is rests on new career resources at the main website and student website. This was rolled out too quickly and is not substantial or working smoothly.  Anything they claim to provide is done better in a dozen different places online. I did a search recently for jobs in logistics in the new career services area, and ALL it came up with were driving jobs for Tutor Time daycare!! 

And now they want you to pursue "stackable" certificates so you can progress your career while you go through school, aka now they want you to take ALL the classes they offer from Associates up to Masters or Doctorate and spend well over 100k. 

Their is little chance for career advancement.  And the pay is 20-30% less than what competitors pay for the same role. As with any big company you have to kiss some serious a$$ to move up or around, but mostly you only make lateral moves and sometimes you have to go back to the bottom of the pay range for a new area. 

I feel like I could burn in hell for enrolling some people I know have no shot of getting through the programs. The open door enrollment policy means anyone can get in and as long as the financial aid keeps coming in to the university they will make sure they stay in school. I just completed my MBA with other students who couldn't write complete sentences or formulate arguments or even speak in front of others. Yet their diploma says MBA just like mine.

And good luck getting a new job with any degree here. You may be able to move up if your company really value your skills, but HR managers drop resumes with university of phoenix on it into the 'circular file'. 

Unless you cannot find any other job (but you should be able to since all of the competitors are still hiring) ONLY, and I mean ONLY work here if you have an exit strategy!!!!!!

This company is going down the crapper - don't have its name on your resume!!

pros:
the job is easy

cons:

review_title: Beware!  A word of advice for potential victims!
pros: I had good benefits while I was there and enjoyed some of the people that I worked with.  I knew that it was only a temporary solution until something better came along so that helped me to get through.
cons: I hated the "sales" of the job which were hidden from me until I got into it more.  They are all about sales and you are only as good as your previous month.  It is so silly and I hated the way management was.  They are not all about the students like they say they are.  They are all about the money!  I could not wait to find something else and get out as quick as possible.  It would not be such a bad job if they would revise their Matrix.  I felt like a telemarketer, required to make 100 + phone calls a day to people who had been called tons of times and hated the fact that I kept calling them.  I was supposed to have a certain amount of "talk time" and customer service time per day.  It was miserable.  The schedule was horrible.  I could go on and on.  I suggest this if you just needed something to get you through until something better comes along in this tough economy but now as a career.  Don't get me wrong, there are some people that enjoy it and are good at it and they can make a career of this.  I just can't tell people to go to school when it is not in their best interest.  I can't tell them to put themselves into debt and go to a school that may not be worth the degree you got if you actually complete it.  The sad thing is, I think that it could be a great place.  If they could be smart and change their ways of doing business.  They lost smart, talented people, because of selfish greedy reason.  They give themselves a bad reputation!  The turnover rate of employees is very higher.  Just beware.

pros: This is my first job out of college and I feel I have learned a lot about working in a professional setting. I am also very appreciative of the MBA degree I obtained here. I am grateful for everything that University of Phoenix has done for their employees.
