review_title: Nothing but a call center sweatshop
job_title: Workforce Solutions Advisor in Costa Mesa, CA
pros: Free tuition, but the degree is from UOP
cons: Micro-managed to the nth degree.  Nobody in management cares about the student experience it is all about the enrollment numbers.  The PBS Front-line documentaries are spot on.  With that being said there are individual enrollment advisors who care about their students, but they are forced out quickly because caring about students leads to lower enrollments

pros: They do offer decent pay and decent benefits...that's really about it. Oh, and I made some good friends.
cons:
I'm not even sure where to begin. FIrstly, the training is  JOKE. It will not help you or give you the tools and skills you need to be successful. The office culture is TERRIBLE! Very hostile, very cut-throat! You are expected to meet a quota, but no one can tell you what that is. 

I went from being a decent "enroller" to "you might want to consider looking for another job" (oh yes, I was outright told this) in less than a week....due to performance? But wait....didn't I just build a class for another campus? And I'm enrolling at national average?? I'm confused....how is this not performing? Oh right - because there's some secret minimum I'm supposed to meet. 

Make no mistake, they over-hire, and then look for ways to single people out for termination. There is no job security, no honesty - you're just a cog in the machine to progress management's careers! And considering I was told in an interview that my interviewer doesn't even acknowledge the degrees from UoP?? Well...I want no part of this scam! I put in my two weeks, and the next day I was treated like a criminal! And let's not get started on the inflammatory accusations.

Read the writing on the wall! There are HUNDREDS of complaints with the BBB from consumers (ie - students). This school is at risk for losing their accreditation due to POOR BUSINESS PRACTICES!! Everything about this job was bait and switch - the benefits, the culture, the schedule, the pay...all of it! DON'T BE TEMPTED!! KEEP LOOKING!! Most of my previous co-workers are actively looking for other employment....after less than a year!

review_title: Beware, corporate politics, greed, and favoritism.
pros: Generally decent pay, a few quality colleagues here and there, and decent benefits, though they recently changed to "exchange" insurance that is ridiculously overpriced.
cons: Management is terrible and focused only on keeping the ship from sinking. Favoritism runs rampant, and the rules don't apply equally to all. They have no interest in helping you grow; they want nothing more from you than to sit in your chair, don't ask questions, and be quiet. I was hired into a very hard job and subsequently went through 4 management changes in under a year. Each one was progressively worse. I was never trained properly. I made a few small mistakes here and there and was never properly coached on improving beyond the tired "don't make this mistake again" speech. The leadership is uninspiring at best and downright hostile at worst. I was disciplined over every minor (and sometimes imaginary) thing I did wrong. I am one to own my mistakes, but they don't care about that. They care about building a file on you so they can bounce you out the door whenever a dispute or disagreement arises. I was let go 3 days after I interviewed with a competitor school last year. This was the worst experience I ever had. A midcareer professional with two graduate degrees, and I was made to feel like a toddler who'd messed his pants every single day. The charade continued right up until the second I was escorted out the door by security.

pros: Good Training, talking to student to help them acheive their goals, good benefits and paid time off

review_title: The UOPX is going down the tube! Do not work for this school!
pros: Short turn around. Five week courses.
cons: Lousy administration.  Reminds me of CTU. The constant flogging of instructors by departments layered on top of each other, you get emails from the copyright police one day and the next you get emails from another department for quality control, but no one ever fixes what is broken in the course room.

review_title: This is a for profit school, and let's just say that none of the profits are invested into the school's employees.
pros: Good work schedule, ok tuition benefits, good overall benefit package, some decent people to work with
cons:
Mindless work that is mastered after a few months, then no challenge exists.  The school doesn't try to challenge its people and if advisors do obtain advanced degrees, advisors definitely don't have the opportunity to use them for any of the advisor jobs.  The compensation structure is a joke, you can work as hard as possible and achieve the best accolades for your position from students and managers, but none of that matters, you will still get the same increase as everyone else, if you are lucky enough to get an increase.

The career advancement is also a joke.  As the company is floundering there are limited positions open around the company, so if you start as an advisor with University of Phoenix, plan on being there for a good long time before getting to move out of that role, or you may have to look outside the company like many others have had to do.  The company doesn't care about keeping its talent, they care about their bottom line, and to them it's more important to pay the lowest possible salary in the industry to their people rather that keep someone with a higher pay who is so much better at working with students.

The management team is clueless and powerless, and that combination is not attractive to any employee.  I have had the opportunity to approach management on several occasions about the lack of opportunity, making changes to the compensation structure, and multiple ways to increase productivity and morale within my assigned territory.  Management presents you with a good sounding line and brushes it aside as soon as you leave their office.  Another thing that the management team have become experts at is dangling the carrot, they discuss great opportunities and changes and tell you that it's coming soon, and keep saying that until everyone realizes that those promises were empty and we really won't see anything better any time soon.  Management also has the amazing talent of micromanaging and focusing on the smallest thing, so even if you are doing a great job for the school and students can't say enough good things about you and you've just finished training 3 of their new people to the point where now they are as bored as you, the manager will ask you why your phone was in the wrong login code for a few minutes.  The concept of reality doesn't really fit through the doors here at UOPX, and it shows with the extreme frustration of many of its employees.

Just to give everyone an idea of what to expect pay wise.  I've worked here for about 3 1/2 years and I am only getting paid about $2500.00 more per year than someone who just started yesterday, and the best part is I get to handle that person's work and train that person to be great at their job because I am the go to person on my team.  The company doesn't provide any incentive to be good at your job and care, but it's amazing that some employees like myself still do care about helping students and team members.

If you have a solid work ethic and you already have advanced degrees do yourself a favor and look elsewhere for a position.  This place is an after high school starter job and nothing more.

review_title: Shrinking opportunities and growing disappointments for College Instructors
job_title: Faculty Facilitator in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Experienced Industry and Education coworkers for networking

Compensation: Started at $900 for a 5 week class, now $1206 after 5 years.
cons:
My combined brick and mortar classroom and online class workload has gone down from 2 -3 per month to 2 -3 per year. 3 campuses recently closed in my area. 

The quality and average abilities of students have also significantly gone down. In contrast to the advertising image of working professionals finishing their degrees, many of the classes I teach are now filled with high school dropouts and continuation school graduates with reading, writing, critical thinking, and classroom behavioral skills far below an average college freshman.

This leaves an instructor with a dilemma. One can maintain Academic Rigor and receive nasty "customer reviews" because many students think they bought a grade higher than the one they did not earn. Then the instructor has to answer a Department Chair inquiry over why a customer was unhappy with his grade. 

The alternative is to downgrade the difficulty of the class, or grade easier by overlooking errors in student work and assignments submitted late. Then the instructor only faces an academic review from the Chair once a year. A slight slap on the wrist for being an "Easy A" is easier to take than frequent customer criticism.

This is the root of their diploma mill reputation.

In addition, this is the first employee stock purchase plan where I lost money on paper. It is merely a "hold" in my portfolio. Many top executives cashed out earlier when the stock was a Wall Street Darling. 

If you are a college instructor don't hang you hat on this corporation. Never forget first and foremost that this is an "at will" for profit corporate employer. You can be terminated, or just stop receiving solicitations at any time without notice or explanation. There is no academic freedom or job security under this regime.

With more stringent Federal oversight over sales tactics and student loans, the future isn't bright.  Try Community College instruction first.  The pay is better and the organization isn't run by a profit motive.

review_title: Started off like a dream job & then gradually turned into a nightmare...
job_title: Customer Care Associate in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Excellent tuition benefits, healthcare package, paid holidays, always had nights & weekends off, consistent schedule, great experience with corporate culture, wonderful for enhancing computer skills
cons:
There was very little opportunity for advancement. When opportunity was presented, it was almost always a lateral move. Within the duration of my 4 years of employment, I interviewed for 4 other positions (all after approximately 1.5 years as a top performer) before I finally received an offer. I also had to work in the new position for 3 months prior to the offer, and I was only offered $200. per year pay increase in this new position.   

Major changes took place so often that one might question the stability of the company. Due to the constant change, there was almost no continuity within performance expectations. Job positions were constantly being restructured, so employees rarely had the opportunity to master their skills & feel good about knowing how to do their job well.

Everything depended how compatible you were with your direct supervisor. I was a top performer who was very well known for my positive contributions for the first 3 out of 4 years.  In that time, I had 5 different managers.  All were excellent except the last one. The last manager I had was extremely excessive with micromanagement. We would have weekly "1 on 1" meetings in a private office where nobody could hear what was being said. If I had conflicting core values with my manager, these meetings would go for hours. There was very little support from upper management when conflict arose with my direct supervisor. As a result, my performance plummeted within about 6 months.  In short, my last manager "coached" me into a bad employee to the extent that I knew I had to resign in order to keep from eventually getting terminated.

job_title: Senior Enrollment Advisor in Phoenix, AZ
pros: The company went thru a plethora of changes within the last 2 years. These changes were supposed to make the University a Top 100 place to work corporation. Up until the performance based matrix was taken away, this was an incredible place to work, with sense of commaradie, as well as opportunities to move up and to other parts of Apollo group. The company had finally grown enough that they realized that more formal training needed to be given not only to managers, but also to new advisors once they started on the floor. The focus on placing the Student first was brilliant, but in doing this, University of Phoenix forgot about those of us who had passionately been doing that all along. There were opportunities for employees that wanted to move up to be nominated for programs and mentorships, as well as less formal ways to help with peer to peer advising.
cons: Unfornunately, Managers resisted the changes that came about, and there was no real LEADERSHIP at ANY level that recognized that talented, passionate employees were and have been moving on for over 2 years now. The employee growth, incentive and promotional matrix was taken away, and replaced with now...3 different programs which have had good points, but ended up leaving growth stagnant. There are broken promises that a "surprise" green rootbeer float on St. Patrick's Day, just can't make up for. More tenured Managers, do not have any idea of how to manage without a matrix, and in the very same VP of Enrollment Webinar praising the advisors for creating relatiionships with our students, we are told that there is no longer overtime...something that you had to qualify for with strong performance. The overtime would often mean an additional entire check per month. Now, working Saturdays and Sundays is mandatory for most regions.

review_title: Work here if you are OK with a Company selling degrees for $$$
pros: There are none - its a job.
cons:
If you are considering working for the University of Phoenix in any Capacity, you need to ask yourself why.  More importantly if it is to provide for your family and put food on the table, then I would say a job is a job.  If however you have ethical standards and feel that an education is a sacred obligation that every student enters into, then I will tell you that this Company is not for you.  

I had to learn really quickly that the University of Phoenix is NOT concerned with the actual students and more with the image of being a higher education degree factory.  Students are able to lie, cheat, and overall get away with flimsy excuses without having any repercussions for their actions. Students are able to post material that is not theirs, make participation posts that are taken 100% from online sources and are not required to read any of the course material.  

Faculty however are expected to post five days a week and grading assignments do not count towards weekly requirements.  Faculty are told to report student academic problems, but then students are not reprimanded when they happen; that is unless you consider a warning to be a reprimand.  Over the past 11 years I have reported close to 450 students; of these students I can recall only 2 that were suspended.  The other 448 all came up with excuses that other faculty didn’t mind if they cheated or plagiarized material.

As someone who works in the IT environment and is responsible for hiring, I can honestly say that I look at University of Phoenix degrees to be 100% useless and the students that obtain them to be underqualified and aside from being bottom of the barrel intern material, are not qualified for the positions they are applying for.

In closing, the University of Phoenix is a pay for your degree school and has had more academic infractions than I care to count.  This is not an education but rather a medium for a person to pay for a piece of paper that is loosely considered to be a degree.  The faculty that teach courses are simply doing it for a paycheck, because they know in their hearts that the schools is a joke and the students that attend are only there to collect a financial aid paycheck.

Your income is based of convincing people without money to go into 10's of thousands of dollars worth of debt.

job_title: Senior Finance Advisor in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Different challenges every day. Helping students achieve there goals is rewarding. Worked with some great people there over the years
cons: High stress job and lack of good management. Lack of understanding from management and success is all about the numbers.

pros: Tuition waiver is the only pro I can think of.  But be careful.
cons: They absolutely do not value their good employees.  Be careful, because they will do you dirty the first chance they get.  Lots of layoffs, I know people still working there who say they go to work every day in fear of losing their job.   And don't be fooled, it's still very much about the "numbers" and "profit"

review_title: There were some great years and some rough ones, but all in all I worked with some great people.
pros: Great opportunity to make money and promote in the early days. Ongoing training was excellent.
cons: As regulation and competition increased it became very difficult to motivate teams. The constant change and gear of change was overwhelming.

pros: Strictly cons today... please see below:
cons: Changed their salary structure for California and I received notice that my new hourly rate is $19 per hour!  Cannot wait to spend all that extra pay!  I have a Doctorate and a Master's Degree and have taught for Phoenix for 6 years and they decided to change my hourly wage to $19...I think the management of the organization should take one of my classes to learn about compensation and employee morale.

job_title: Operations Analyst II in Tempe, AZ
pros: Bachelor's is fully paid by the company. You just have to pay for resources. Masters can also be fully paid if you space out ur classes as there are caps.
cons: Health benefits aren't very good. Vacation is very limited caping @5weeks after 7years of service. No paid maternity leave and no future plans of changing despite the federal changes.

job_title: Enrollment Counselor in Virginia Beach, VA
pros: Pay was decent and when I was there the tuition for Master's and Bachelor was free...that is no longer!
cons: Pay was good, but the negative environment that came down from upper managment was daunting. I absolutley hated going to work, When I was there it was a sweat shop. The University of Chains is what we liked to call it. I hear that the new management is even worse than when I left which I though would never be possible. Everything from the Regional Director, to the Campus Director.

pros: Great team environment, good corporate culture
cons: Back Stabbers!!!  They say one thing and the management (I worked under) only look out for themselves...everyone is disposable!!

pros: I was able to obtain my Masters for free during my employment with the company.
cons: The University experienced major changes during my time there; I was an enrollment counselor and the changes had an impact on the way we were compensated and how we operated. There was a huge layoff as well so that had an impact on morale.

review_title: Entry level job not a career

review_title: Still a good place to work

cons: Instability of job security. Negative press spins make things a little stressful. Recent reductions in workforce.

cons: Constant changes including layoffs. There was always a lawsuit going on and it made it hard to focus on the positives of working there.

pros: 5 weeks of vacation which you will need desperately.  All the other benefits are minuscule!

pros: Freedom to work my own hours. Opportunity to use my knowledge to assist students. Flexibility in choice of classes. It has a good reputation

pros: In my position, I get to work from home. I have total control over my schedule and feel appreciated by management.

pros:
Great education experience and included in your benefits

Your credentials and experience mean little or nothing.

review_title: Great place to work until the for-profit education sector got turned upside down

review_title: A company that is losing ground, quickly

pros: Pay, benefits, and time off. The was plenty of paid time off and they didn't mind you using it.

cons: Sales type environment.  Job was very telephone based.  Must meet sales type goals.  Always the threat of losing your job if not enough students enroll through you.

pros: The ability to change the lives of students. Great faculty members to work with. Great team work among your peers.

pros: You can count on a steady paycheck. I love my coworkers and the health benefits are great.

pros: Students are great, work is rewarding.

review_title: Exceptional, I recommend that you give them a try.
